The mud and vehicle's physics feel great. The game feels quite immersive and true to life due to the fact that damage done to the landscape by going over and back on the same route is saved making the route harder to traverse each and every time. It should be noted that the game is quite slow paced when moving through mud (like 5km/h type slow) making the moments you reach that precious tarmac all the more enjoyable. The game is well balanced, no one vehicle feels op when compared to the rest.
i don't normally like getting mud all over my extremities, but this really did wet my whistle and tickle my toes

the game is so much more of a chore to play than anything that the old demo was, they turned a fun terrain deformation sandbox and added a TON of useless and arbitrary length to do what should be a somewhat simple task into a fucking chore and a half. I get that it's rough and muddy terrain(which I am very much used to in real life because of where i live and have worked), but everything is so damned clunky and slow and it's like the game is fighting you the entire time.

the FIRST actual level of the game, has the lumber mill and the logging pad on LITERAL opposite sides of the map, and they require you to use vehicles that are very very slow and cumbersome to control...it's a sheer annoyance encased in a sweet candy shell that very quickly start to taste very very bitter.

Bought this game on sale for 80% off and I must say I'd have been happy to pay fill price (¬£20) for it. Keep in mind I have Autistic Spectrum Disorder and a large part of why I love this game is the incredible simulation of heavy vehicles. From the mud and water dynamics around the tyres to the engine sounds and gear-shifts, brake pressure releases. It is extremely satisfying. I am someone who plays War Thunder almost exclusively for the "tanks in the mud" appeal and Mudrunner has been on my short-list for a long time. I am so glad I picked this up, this game will help me relax to the beautiful theatre of Heavy Vehicles slurping through the mud ans the Diesel engine roars, working for every inch we progress. I love it. Music to my eyes.

I will keep this game open in the background all day while I work/do other things. I will pretend my character is stopping for a nap when I park up and switch tasks. What is even more awesome, is that if you leave AFK for long enough, the driver literally does take a nap. 10/10 GOTY.

Well to be honest this game is a lot of fun. You can do missions and free roam. Best part of the game is the off-road driving.  The off-road driving is very realistic and the graphics are fantastic. I do recommend this game to the public

Good game to kill time. I see a lot of complaints about vehicle control when trying to go fast, Several points to be made:
1. Real world physics. (Pretty close)
2. Nearly every vehicle in the game is based on old Soviet military technology. (1950's to early 70's) As such the springs are stiff (bouncy) and shocks are non existent on most of the trucks.  
3. The tires. Military type balloon tires and/or partially deflated tires for, you guessed it, mud running.
All these factors add up to vehicles designed for going slow and steady. 
 And the title is a bit misleading. Instead of MudRunner it should be named MudCrawler.

Good concept but VERY poorly executed, multiplayer is rather pointless, you each get your own set of vehicles and theres no "multiplayer" aspect to it besides you can see eachother, objectives aren't shared, vehicles aren't shared, resources aren't shared, TLDR it plays as singleplayer. Gameplay is pretty thin, you can set AWD and Diff lock on and just hold W through most obstacles, theres never a reason to turn off these options.
Given that Snowrunner is basically a full price clone of this game its safe to say these games are both low effort cash grabs. My friend and I gave this game a couple of good tries but didn't have any fun at any point. Refunded.
Would not recommend.

It should also be noted that we both paid under $5 for this game and it was not worth that, so sales should not encourage you to purchase this.

[h1]CHORERUNNER[/h1]

Mudrunner is an off-road driving simulator set in Siberia. It's a slow but peaceful experience that definitely won't be for everyone. It wasn't for me. The game went from fun to boring quickly. There's not enough content or incentive to play with what we have. There are also other problems that I have listed below.
Personally, I can't recommend it. Still, if you're looking for a game about driving a truck through the wilderness, you may give it a chance. It's a niche genre, where you can't be too picky. 

[b]Story[/b]
No story mode.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
First and foremost. If you did operate anything in real life, then you'll find that the simulation part of the game isn't good. Almost everything is simplified and far from being realistic. If you expect something truly faithful to the real thing - you won't find it here.
The biggest selling point of the game - mud - is really fun. It can be a real struggle to get your car/truck out of it, which is not something common in gaming. How many games outside of Mudrunner, Snowrunner, and Spintires does it? Not many.
You have a few options to get out of the mud. By force but it can often backfire, with a second truck, or with a winch. Winching itself is done fairly well. Bigger trucks need to be attached to larger trees. Trunks or smaller trees may be enough for cars/small trucks. You simply can't do whatever.
The driving itself is not that good though. Almost all the trucks feel the same no matter the terrain. You barely feel the size and power of the machines that you're driving. 
This may not be a problem for some people, but I need to point it out. It feels like there's not enough incentive to make you play the game. I did finish almost all the missions, then did some freeriding... and it was enough for me. I couldn't force myself to do any jobs. I think that a currency and something to buy for it (like fuel/trucks/upgrades) would help a lot. Maybe an option to invest in your own business? Unfortunately, we got nothing.
I also dislike the controls. Just driving? Fine. Doing anything else? One big chore. Moving trees into the truck was especially painful.
The tutorial is poorly made. You won't get much out of it.

[b]Visuals and Audio[/b]
Visually, Mudrunner is solid. Certain textures and models aren't the highest quality (mainly things in the background, like trees or buildings), but the trucks themselves are great... as long as you're not looking at their interiors. They are just a low-quality copy-paste, that you don't want to look at.
The dynamic environment helps to hide ugly elements of the game. Nights and foggy weather are especially beautiful, and they help create a peaceful atmosphere.
Enjoy the sounds of trucks, because there's nothing else. No music and no radio.


[b]Technicalities[/b]
No stuttering or performance drops. It would be hard to achieve fps drops anyway, when the game is locked on 60. 
I did have one random crash. When it comes to smaller issues: no slider to change FOV, certain features are limited when playing in coop, and bugs with the physics of trucks.

This game is super boring and not worth trying. You can't customize vehicles at all, you are thrown into woods with super old/slow trucks. There is no real campaign. The tutorial is very lacking... The only reason it got popular is because YouTubers have played it.

Since you cant buy the OG Spintire by OOVEE because of trademark problem with FOCUS, you can only try their best physic engine with this game.
But if you manage to find keys of the game with all dlc for a reasonable price then go for it (can go up to 500euros for the china dlc).

Cons:
-Of course graphics are outdated, the gameplay seems rather slow compared to snowrunner.
-Missions are just exploration and hauling logs.
-Multiplayer is dead unless you play with friends. 
-Not a colorfull game

But the way the vehicle behave and the feedback they give is by far superior to snowrunner.
Pro:
-One of the best offroad game games out there (even better with mods).
-Seeing the trucks going out of the mud is very satisfying as they get dirty and throw mud particles everywere.
-Because of the slower gamepace the vehicles are balanced and dont seem overpowered (like snowrunner), they have 
 actualy weight to them, not bouncy like the sequel.
-Once you understand the game, Mudrunner is by far easyer to play than Snowrunner because the engine is just superior (in Mudrunner each wheel is a connection to the road, wheras in Snowrunner the connection is in the middle of the axe, you can see that when the truck a ripping sideways)
-The manual gearbox with autotrust so you dont spend hours on the W or the controler trigger to advance

[b]MudRunner - A Muddy Middle Ground[/b]

Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

"MudRunner" delivers an authentic off-road simulation experience, but its appeal may be limited to a specific audience. Released in 2017, the game's dedication to realism and challenging terrain sets it apart, yet it also falls short in certain aspects.

One of the game's strengths lies in its impressive mud physics and environmental details. Navigating through various terrains with a diverse selection of off-road vehicles can be both satisfying and challenging. The sense of accomplishment when conquering difficult landscapes is a testament to the game's commitment to simulation.

The variety of vehicles and the open-world maps contribute to the game's replay value. Each vehicle feels distinct, offering a different experience in terms of handling and capabilities. The expansive maps, featuring diverse landscapes, provide ample opportunities for exploration and experimentation.

However, "MudRunner" might not resonate with a broader gaming audience. The deliberate pace and emphasis on realism make it less accessible for those seeking a more casual or action-packed gaming experience. The absence of a compelling narrative or structured progression may leave some players yearning for a stronger sense of purpose in their off-road adventures.

While the cooperative multiplayer mode adds a social element, the game's appeal may still be niche, catering primarily to enthusiasts of the off-road simulation genre. Additionally, the graphics and overall presentation, while serviceable, don't necessarily push the boundaries of what is expected in modern gaming.

In summary, "MudRunner" is a solid off-road simulation, but its appeal is likely confined to a specific audience. If you have a passion for realistic off-road challenges and don't mind the lack of a traditional narrative structure, "MudRunner" can offer an engaging and immersive experience. However, for those seeking a more diverse or fast-paced gaming experience, the muddy middle ground might not be compelling enough to warrant the journey.

Fantastic game.

I love how they handle the cockip camera, it's so great to look around from inside the cockpit. In all other games, there are buttons to look around or even if you use the mouse to look around they always make you look from where your character's face is. In this game you use the mouse to look around but your character moves his head around so you can look outside the window, to the back and to the side almost as if looking out the window and can actually see around properly and realistically.

I'm sure people already talked about the various great features of this game and how good it is in general so I wanted to mention this specific thing I like about it.

I finished all missions in hardcore mode and always from the cockpit (only used outside cameras when stationary) and had a great sense of achievement. It is great that when you make a mistake you can't save load or anything like that so you need to always plan ahead, drive carefully and if you roll over your truck you need to live with the consequences.

SteamDeck - 10/10
I remember when Spin Tires originally came out and seeing videos of it's impressive simulation of mud physics. I was impressed but not convinced to buy in to what looked like a tech demo simulation of what could be a bigger game. To say I'm pleasantly surprised by Mud Runner would be just the surface level of what I could say about this game. I have Almost 10 hours in this game, and that was only spent doing the optional challenges. Those optional challenges that the game recommends you do before playing the main single player part of the game were so fun and genuinely challenging that it sucked me into this game. I played this entirely on my SteamDeck and was amazed by not only how well it ran, but how good the controller feels when controlling the game. I picked this up for 4 bucks, total package, which I believe is a great asking price for just the challenges alone. If you think navigating tricky, muddy terrain sounds fun definitely pick this up.

Want to mud bog? Want to drive soviet era timber equipment? Want to drive American timber equipment? Play this game!

[h3] +Pros [/h3]
+Mud and earth physics that are very accurate.
+Workshop
+Many maps to play on with varying degrees of difficulty.
+Post release DLC that is pretty good. Quite a bit of it is free, as well.

[h3] ~Neutrals [/h3]
~This game is a slow burn , and takes time to play. I've played it for 30 hours, and most of the stock and DLC maps take roughly 2 hours to complete. I'm an experienced SpinTires and Snowrunner player, so noobs will spend more time that I did.

[h3] -Cons [/h3]
-Crashes frequently after reaching more than an hour in 1 sitting. Save often, and reboot the game every 30 or so minutes to avoid progress loss.
-Camera.
-Color palette is too close to photo-realism, and ends up looking extremely washed out.
-Sudden music when completing objectives.

Ignoring all the dumb comments. Step by step guide of the game is as follows.
Step 1. Take truck to find logs
Step 2. Use truck to bring the logs
Step 3. Dump the logs cause you went to fast
Step 4. Get mad and quit the game

Step 7. Take both trucks and finally deliver the logs. 
Step 8. Profit

MudRunner Review - Patience Is Key üåßÔ∏èüöú

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (4 Stars) - A hidden gem for the patient gamer

MudRunner, a game I heartily recommend to most players, is a title that excels both in its graphical and mechanical construction. In this game, you'll find yourself immersed in a world where precision and patience are the keys to success.

üåÑ Graphics and Mechanics - A Well-Built World üñ•Ô∏èüîß
MudRunner impresses with its attention to detail, both graphically and mechanically. The environment is beautifully crafted, immersing you in a world where every puddle, every tree, and every mud pit feels authentic. The robust mechanics behind the game's physics engine give a sense of realism that's hard to come by.

üöö Missions and Challenges - A Test of Skill and Patience üìã
The heart of MudRunner lies in its missions and challenges. From delivering garage parts to locked garages, transporting logs from point A to B, to exploring the vast map, every task demands precision. The beauty is that you have a variety of vehicles at your disposal, each strategically placed on the map and customizable in your garage, allowing you to tailor your ride for the task at hand.

üö¶ Patience Is Paramount ‚è≥
In this game, rushing headlong into challenges isn't the path to success. MudRunner rewards those who approach each task with caution and patience. It's the most crucial skill you can possess in the game. When you embrace patience, MudRunner transforms from a potentially dull experience into a highly enjoyable and satisfying one.

MudRunner is a game where the journey is as important as the destination. It's not about speed, but about the art of off-road maneuvering and conquering the unpredictable terrain. So, take a deep breath, go slow, and savor every mud-splattered moment. If you're looking for a game that rewards a measured approach and a steady hand, MudRunner is a hidden gem well worth your time. üåßÔ∏èüõ§Ô∏èüöú

Disclaimer: I spent more time playing Snow-Runner, hence the low play time on this game, but BOTH PLAY THE SAME.  I own Snow- in Epic Games, so I can't make an equal shit review like I did below.

Did you want to drive a truck?  Many trucks? Do you want to drive a truck that when you steer it goes where you want it to? Did you actually want to drive to an objective without it taking hours? 

OR Do you want to always drive at 5 mph on any terrain, and anything faster you will spin out of control?

This game SUUUUCCCCCKKKKKKS.  I, for the life of me, have no idea why, between this game, and Snow-runner, does ANYONE compare it to ATS.

I have a game I can compare it to...Ship Simulator: EXTREME.  Where the ships go as fast as the trucks in this game, and the ships control as shAt as molasses, just like the trucks in this game.

I've never not wanted to play a game so much until it comes to this game.  Every time I start it I forget how much it sucked the last time I played it.  I don't want -to get stuck all the time-; to spend hours getting myself -unstuck-, for it to happen again 3 minutes later.

The terrain is shAt. The controls are shAt.  I don't understand how any sim living in this environment gets anywhere.
It's like Canada (or West Virginia) on steroids.  Going to get a gallon of milk I feel they would have to pack survival gear because there is a possibility they aren't coming back.  It's like Oregon Trail, but with gas.

How, anyone in their mind, would ever want to play a game, where, there is constant failure every time you start it....
oh....That would be the Dark Souls franchise.  This game is the Dark Souls of truck driving.

If you are that, enjoy this shAt game.

Although it''s been completely superseded by its great sequel, MudRunner was a great mid-term solution between the great idea that was Spintires and the completely evolved SnowRunner.
It's still a very fun game to play, and it can be even less forgiving than SnowRunner, since you can't recall big trucks back to a garage. If you tip over, either mount a rescue mission or forget about that truck. Asphalt physics are a bit off, but mud... oh, that's where this simulator shines.

MudRunner is not a game for everyone, as it caters to a certain audience who crave a realistic and challenging off-road experience. If you're looking for fast-paced action or a simple arcade racer, this might not be your cup of tea. However, for those who appreciate the thrill of conquering nature's challenges in heavy-duty vehicles, this is the game for you. The game's realistic physics, immersive sound, co-op multiplayer, and a still active modding community, even in 2023 and onwards make it an enduring and rewarding experience for off-road simulation fans.

"MudRunner" is an off-road simulation game that immerses players in the challenging and often treacherous world of navigating through thick mud, dense forests, and rugged terrain. Developed by Saber Interactive and published by Focus Home Interactive, this game offers a realistic and exhilarating experience for both off-road enthusiasts and those looking for a unique gaming challenge.

The heart of "MudRunner" lies in its faithful recreation of off-road driving. You take control of powerful, customizable vehicles, including trucks and all-terrain vehicles, as you traverse harsh landscapes that pose a constant challenge. The physics engine is a standout feature, accurately simulating the interactions between your vehicle's tires, the terrain, and the mud, creating a dynamic and immersive off-road experience.

The game's environments are expansive and diverse, featuring dense forests, rivers, rocky hills, and, of course, lots and lots of mud. Each map presents a series of challenging objectives, such as delivering cargo or rescuing vehicles, which require careful planning, strategy, and sometimes a bit of trial and error. The sense of accomplishment when you successfully navigate your vehicle through a particularly tough section of mud or terrain is immensely rewarding.

"MudRunner" offers both single-player and multiplayer modes, allowing you to team up with friends to tackle the challenging missions or engage in freeform exploration. Multiplayer enhances the experience, as coordination and teamwork become essential for success, and it's also where the game's community shines with custom mods and additional content.

While "MudRunner" excels in many aspects, it's not without its quirks and potential frustrations. The game's learning curve can be steep, especially for newcomers to off-road simulation. The user interface and controls may take some getting used to, and the lack of a traditional tutorial can make the initial hours somewhat daunting.

Additionally, the game's pace can be slow, as off-road driving demands patience and precision. Some players may find this deliberate pace enjoyable, while others might prefer a faster, more action-packed experience.

In summary, "MudRunner" is a niche game that delivers a remarkably authentic and satisfying off-road simulation experience. It caters to enthusiasts of the genre who crave the challenges of navigating tough terrain, battling mud, and mastering their vehicles. While it may not be everyone's cup of tea due to its learning curve and methodical gameplay, those who appreciate realism and a unique challenge will find "MudRunner" to be a muddy, thrilling adventure that captures the essence of off-road exploration. Get ready to embrace the wild, dirty world of off-road driving and discover the joys and trials of conquering the elements one mudslide at a time.

Bought this game while it was on sale. One of the best trucking experiences I have had for less than a tenner. Going back to this game after playing Snowrunner for so long was a welcome change of pace. Most of the trucks are different between games which is a plus. New players will have a bit of a learning curve to get through at first as it isn't exactly the most new player friendly game. Game-play is simple and enjoyable as you go through the game one map at a time. Although the experiences you go through are the same on every map, there is a challenge mode for a bit of a shakeup. The games colour palette itself Id say is more on the realistic side but can be very eerie especially at night time. Mod support is a plus for keeping the game more fresh. Only grudges I have with this game is you have to manually release your winch constantly and clunky UI (Which is expected of a game thats been out that long). Crane controls are really disorienting to use but are rewarding when you get used to them. Overall id give this game a 8 out of 10.

 Id recommend anyone to play this game if they ever get the chance

In general, this is a hardcore, realistic driving game in voxel dirt. You failed and your truck is stuck? You drive carelessly and overturn? –íring another truck and pull yourself out. Another thing to praise is great atmosphere. The game gives very authentic look of wild eastern forests of Russia, far from big cities. The forest, all the machines, the dirt, all places look very-very true!

While the game itself is pretty entertaining, I cannot recommend it due to various annoyances.

First and most important is that there is no way to compare different vehicles or see what equipment is compatible with them. Without any indication of the differences, there is little to no reason to switch between them, especially when you can just 'make do' with whatever you have currently selected.

The second problem is that the core gameplay is extremely similar in every single map or mission, to the point of becoming monotonous (even with just my 14h of playtime). This is exacerbated by the fact that there is no way to fully supply a lumber mill in a single trip (at least not without resorting to cheesy physics exploits), so you are forced to do repeat trips.

Aside from the points above, it is rather frustrating that there is little to no visual indication of which terrain can be easily crossed and which terrain will bog you down to your axles. Blindly fording rivers is also an exercise in frustration, as it is impossible to predict which parts are traversable and which aren't.

Honestly, if they added a bit more info on the vehicles and had destinations require different amounts of cargo, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game.

If any of my readers know of Ice Road Truckers, then just know that I feel like Hugh Rowland or Alex Deborgorski whilst I traverse the muddy terrains which this game kindly provides me with. The engine sounds are subpar with blocky quantization levels which can be heard when the fps drops - happens a lot! I do love driving the massive Soviet Era trucks, but I feel the 4x4 jeep type vehicles are so damn underpowered that I simply roll my eyes at the thought of driving them through a small puddle on this game. 
There is a huge problem with my Logitech G29 steering wheel pedals. I feel that this game is poorly optimised for my steering wheel because when I press the accelerator, the truck keeps the brake on and it looks rather stupid whilst my HUD bobs back and forth to indicate movement. That's the biggest reason that caused me to stop playing this game. If you have a Logitech G29 then I'd recommend to you to sell it, buy a new wheel and live in the present because frankly that steering wheel is bloody old!

Summary: it's a good game but be wary of your steering wheel. If you have a keyboard then I feel sorry for you!

This game has an exceptionnal physics simulation. The terrain deformation is amazing, mud sticks to your wheels, you can see the [i]trucks[/i] deforming when handling rough terrain... The way the vehicle interacts with the ground has no equal, really.

But then the game looks bleak, and there isn't much of a game, really. Every map is about the same thing : pick a truck, explore and place whatever you need where you need it to repair and refuel or transfer cargo from truck A to truck B, then pick up some wood and deliver it. I get it, it's more of an excuse to drive the vehicles and give the player a goal, but that's all. It's not a bad thing, it plays kind of like a puzzle game, "what am I gonna do to deliver that wood here" is a nice problem to solve, but it certainly is something you need to be aware of.

It's a good thing you don't need to spend time advancing a career mode to enjoy what there is, but it's also a bit... lacking. The little brother game, Snowrunner, has a much simplified physics (still great, better than most games, just not on par with this one), but it's a better game overall, as it looks better (it's important to enjoy the scenery when you're crawling at 5 km an hour, and gives you many more excuses to carry stuff from A to B. Whether the career progression is a good or bad things will depend on your personal taste.

Still, I do recommend MudRunner. You can get everything it has to offer for the price of a cofee to go during a sale, and thr modding community makes sure it won't go stale. However, if you're looking for a game that is more game-ish rather than a mud physics framework, I would recommend Snowrunner instead. Be aware though that the little brother has a shit-ton of paid DLC, so if you really do enjoy it, it might cost you quite a bit to collect everything you'd like to have. That being said, the base game is good enough to start.

And in case of doubt, buy MudRunner. It's cheap and you'll quickly know if crawling through the mud at snail pace in a hulking mechanical beast is your thing or not. As for myself, I enjoy it very much and find this calm gameplay very soothing, but your mileage may vary.

MudRunner Review

Games are great because they let you do anything or be anyone. You can be Aloy, an adventurous warrior adept at killing robotic animals in a far-flung future. You can explore entire planets and travel through a vast galaxy in No Man‚Äôs Sky. In Everything, you can be, well, anything. In Spintires: Mudrunner, your goal is to move logs around a particularly muddy patch of land.

That‚Äôs perhaps a little unfair of us, though. This is an impressive off-road simulation title that, while on the surface may appear dull as dishwater, is surprisingly compelling. As we said, the basic objective in the main game is to traverse treacherous terrain in heavy duty vehicles, delivering timber from A to B. It sounds like a simple enough task, but there are a number of factors working against you.

One of them is the brilliant physics simulation at the heart of Mudrunner. The trucks are slow, heavy things with a convincing weight and realistic suspension that reacts as you‚Äôd expect to the conditions at hand. Equally, the mud and water react dynamically to your vehicle as you drive. Deep tracks are carved in the muck as you push through, your tires clogging with earth and slipping in the increasingly poor conditions. Water displaces realistically and washes the mud from your wheels. Rivers have currents that can force you off course or tip you over if you‚Äôre not careful.

When on sale, this game is a good bargain. But not for everyone: This is a very well-made simulation, which is very slow paced.

Mud runner is a very unique game: This is a rock (or rather mud) crawler simulator. You must drive off-road with mostly USSR trucks. There are other vehicles, but these are kind of useless compared to appropriately equipped trucks. There are many maps to complete. The objective is to transport wood from specific points to sawmills.

The cool thing is that you can solve every map the way you want. There is no money, nor time limit. Just your own choice of vehicle, equipment, and paths to reach the goals. You can explore the map to unlock garages where you can equip your trucks (with trailers, tanks, cranes, etc.). You can also find vehicles ‚Äúlost‚Äù in the map, and quickly remove the fog of war by reaching special watch towers.

PRO:
* The graphics and sounds are really good and appropriate.
* Physics simulations are top notch. Probably one of the best.
* The immersion is surprisingly good, especially in cockpit view: from the sounds of the swamps to water streams clearing the mud from your tires, you really feel in are deep in the bog!
* Gamepad ergonomics are good.

CON:
* Very slow pace: not for everyone. This is a simulator, therefore, like in real life, you will craw at the speed of a running man.
* There is not much variety: As soon as you understand what and how to do things properly, the game becomes kind of easy, it is just a matter of doings things slowly‚Ä¶
* I would I liked more challenging or originality in maps. Only a very few maps have mountains, most of them are just the usual forest and swamps.

Now, I believe all the cons have been improved in the sequel snow runner.

All in all, this is an original and entertaining game if you just want to ‚Äúrelax‚Äù with a slow driving simulator.

Title: MudRunner: A Muddy Adventure Worth Getting Stuck In

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5)

MudRunner, the ultimate off-road driving experience, immerses players in the challenging and gritty world of navigating treacherous terrains and conquering the unforgiving power of nature. This realistic driving simulator delivers an adrenaline-fueled adventure that will put your skills and patience to the test.

One of the standout features of MudRunner is its attention to detail when it comes to recreating the mud-filled environments. From dense forests and rocky hills to swampy marshes and rivers, every terrain feels meticulously crafted. The physics-based mud simulation is superb, making each tire spin, slide, and dig its way through the muck with impressive realism. The sense of weight and the struggle against the elements create a unique and immersive driving experience.

The game offers a variety of challenging missions and tasks to undertake, ranging from simple deliveries to intricate rescue operations. The open-world maps are vast and provide ample opportunities for exploration and discovery. Every mission presents its own set of challenges, forcing players to carefully plan their routes, utilize winches and differential locks, and make strategic decisions to overcome obstacles and reach their destination.

The selection of vehicles in MudRunner is diverse and caters to different play styles. From sturdy trucks and off-road behemoths to nimble scouts, each vehicle has its own strengths and weaknesses. The sensation of handling these vehicles feels authentic, and mastering their nuances adds an extra layer of satisfaction to the gameplay.

MudRunner also offers a multiplayer component, allowing players to team up and tackle challenges together. Coordinating with friends or fellow drivers adds an exciting social element and enhances the cooperative nature of the game. Overcoming obstacles as a team is immensely rewarding and can lead to some truly memorable moments.

While MudRunner excels in its realistic and immersive gameplay, it may not appeal to everyone. The slow pace and deliberate nature of off-road driving can be seen as a downside for those seeking more fast-paced action. Additionally, the lack of a traditional narrative might leave some players craving a more structured and engaging storyline.

In conclusion, MudRunner delivers a compelling and authentic off-road driving experience. The attention to detail, challenging terrains, and realistic physics create an immersive world that rewards patience, skill, and strategic thinking. Whether you're a fan of off-road adventures or simply crave a unique driving experience, MudRunner is a muddy delight worth getting stuck in. So gear up, embrace the mud, and prepare for a thrilling journey that will push your driving abilities to their limits.

MudRunner is a phenomenal game that left a lasting impression on me. From the moment I tackled the treacherous terrains and got behind the wheel of powerful off-road vehicles, I was hooked. The game's realistic physics and dynamic mud simulation create an immersive and challenging experience like no other. The attention to detail in the environments and vehicle mechanics is commendable, making every muddy trail and obstacle feel authentic. The sense of accomplishment that comes with successfully navigating through difficult terrain is incredibly satisfying. The variety of maps and missions, as well as the option to play cooperatively, provide endless hours of engaging gameplay. Overall, MudRunner is a must-play for fans of off-road simulation games, delivering a thrilling and immersive off-road adventure that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

It's nice trucking game, easy to get into and relaxing to play but can also offer bit of a challenge with hardcore mode If you want to bother. There is also co-op mode so you can play with friend. I highly recommend getting it on sale where you can pick both game and expansion for about $5

[h1] Pros [/h1]

- Good truck selection, basically all famous Soviet machines are in the game, American Wilds Expansion also adds few cool American trucks and pickups. Vehicle mods are also decent, you can add stuff like cranes, extra repair equipment and such.
- Vehicle physics for muddy roads are well made, weight of your truck can easily get you stuck proper if you are not careful.
- There are "regular" maps and "challenges" which are fun. Maps are not too big but not small either, perfect size for about hour or two of gameplay per map.
- There is no bazillion DLC's like with Snowrunner.

[h1] Cons [/h1]

- Optimization is not the best, I get fps drops in some areas, especially if truck is loaded with cargo.
- Game can become bit repetitive quickly, basically end goal of every map is to deliver logs to lumber station, It would been nice if there was multiple cargo delivery objectives (Snowrunner improved on this fortunately).
- Vehicle physics on paved roads is hot mess, luckily there isn't many paved roads.

I am still wondering wheather to recommend this game or not. It is definitelly unique, I like the graphics, I like the physics how is used in this game, driving all trucks seems to be quite realistic for me. Therefore I think game is implemented very well.

What I think about the game content? First you need to finish a tutorial - it explains very well how not to get stuck in mud - there is always a way how to get unstuck.

Then you can start the main game. Goal is quite simple - to find a log station, load truck with logs and then go to the lumber mill. There are about 8 various trucks in the whole area. You need to find that truck to unlock it and then you can swith between all unlocked trucks. I recommend to find some bigger truck, then go to the garage. There you can convert truck to log carrier, then you can load some logs and go to the lumber mill. All of this is much easier said than done- because you need to travel quite long distance with each truck, quite long distance to lumber mill, you also need to go to the fuel station to refuel your trucks from time to time. Therefore it actually takes quite a lot of time, this game is slow paced. You need to spend a lot of time in mud before you deliver your first truck load of logs.

This game is based on few quite simple principles, therefore you don't need to think too much while playing it. This is actually quite opposite of racing games - you are going at speed like 15 mph most of the time :-)

MudRunner is a heavy-duty off-road driving simulator that incorporates fully interactive physics to allow players to experience realistic driving in challenging conditions. The game focuses on driving large tractor-trailers and ensuring the transportation of timber and other loads over various obstacles and difficult terrains.

While this game is a great experience for some players, I can understand how you might find it boring after a few minutes of play. Without enough interest in heavy vehicle driving simulators in challenging conditions, it can be difficult to find fun in this game.

However, the game offers a wide variety of games and game modes that may be of interest to those interested in truck driving. Players can drive through different maps and terrains, face challenges and complete various tasks. The game also offers a multiplayer mode, which can be an interesting experience for those who want to team up with other players and overcome obstacles together.

Overall, MudRunner can be an interesting game for players who are interested in driving simulators of heavy vehicles in challenging conditions. However, I recommend the game only to those who have a genuine interest in this area, whether for keyboard and mouse or steering wheel play.

MudRunner is the most relaxing "puzzle" game I've played. FOV Report: Very poor & non existent

Genuinely horrible FOV with no slider, config files, or as far as I know mods to fix it. Steer clear of this one.

I'm on a field of view crusade. We live in a world where raytracing is common, but a basic quality of life field of view slider is not. There is no excuse other than lazy developers to not include one. If you agree, and want to see more accessible, comfortable gaming for everyone, join me on my crusade and start encouraging devs everywhere to include FOV support.

Excellent game.  When you think driving games you think racing, or fast paced Twisted Metal shoot em ups, you don't think 15 MPH in mud, it SOUNDS boring, it totally isn't.  That said it def has some rough edges.

Pros:
- Alcoholism in SIberia
- The land actually remembers what you did, if you rut up a passage too much you'll have to find a new way, very realistic
- The vehicles, though slightly limited, are nifty, random Russian jeeps, Chevy Blazers, etc
- Relaxing, this is a great game for people who are sick of games with timers or people shooting at you

Cons:
- The driving physics they tried to nail, in real life deep mud and stuff your steering IS a bit wonky, this feels too wonky
- I wish you could change your tire pressure, because when ya DO drive on a real road its still all over the place cuz the tires have like 15 lbs of pressure
- The views or lack thereof, and constantly having to shift them  with the right stick, gets old quick
- Cruise control, you cant change the view just put it in neutral or whatever

Overall this is an excellent game, certainly not for everyone, and don't expect a TON of excitement, but when you're in the mood for it, it's alot of fun.

I have to say, as a game developer myself, I was thoroughly impressed with MudRunner. The level design was exceptional and the attention to detail was remarkable. As I played through each level, I found myself analyzing the game mechanics and studying how the developers were able to create such a seamless and immersive experience.

The physics engine was also incredibly impressive. The way the mud and water behaved, as well as the various types of vehicles and equipment available, made for a truly engaging and challenging experience. As someone who has worked with physics engines in the past, I can say that MudRunner's is one of the best I've seen.

Overall, I think MudRunner is a fantastic game that any game developer or level designer should play. It's a great example of how to create a cohesive and challenging experience that keeps players engaged from start to finish. I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for inspiration and wants to see what's possible in game development.

Lack of content.

I've downloaded the DLC, but even then, the gameplay is lacking. The first mission is to deliver wood. Fair enough. Issue is the only route is the longest route around the map. It's extremely grindy and for no reason that I can determine.

I haven't completed the first mission either.

On top of that, there's no incentive to even do any jobs. Fuel is unlimited and free. Trucks are simply unlocked by driving around the map. 

While it's nice to have free options when getting started, there is NO currency in this game whatsoever. (I haven't completed the first mission but it should be clear if money plays a role or not). THere are no trucks to buy, no garages to purchase, no business to expand. The gameplay is dull.

THe driving also leaves alot to be desired. All the trucks feel the same and the terrain hardly affects how the trucks handle. Driving on asphalt feels exactly the same as driving on dirt.

The interiors have the same dashboard copied and pasted. The vehicles in this game are licensed by real manufacturers so I'm surprised that no effort was spared into designing the vehicles or the handling charateristics.

There are the challenges which honestly, is what I expected from the missions in the campaign.

I thought this game would be interesting but honestly, it just feels like a chore. There are no sounds or music during the game play. There's no traffic. there's hardly any content here. This feels like a basic indie game with no replayability. (Although, for what it's worth, the challenges are somewhat fun imo).

Had potential. but is lacking on content.

I like the concept of the game, and see how it can be a challenge to play.  The big let down for me is it feels over-exaggerated when it comes to the effects of the environment on the vehicles. Sure, if all of the muddy roads in the world had the consistency of oatmeal, you'd be getting stuck every 5 minutes.  But even driving on asphalt, even wet asphalt is dicey, or should I say icy. If all of the vehicles in the world reacted like this game, nobody would get anywhere or get anything done. I do see where they are going with the game, but it's more frustration than fun.  First attempt to drive an unloaded semi truck from a short relatively level muddy road to get out on the asphalt and you get stuck. Can that happen in real life? Sure, if you let the roads become a swamp! I get it, that's the challenge, but it just doesn't feel realistic enough for me.  Otherwise I do like the dynamic nature of the road changing, and mud and rocks moving, and the overall concept of the game, but it just feels ridiculously overexaggerated.

I just got back to Mudrunner because I bought a Thrustmaster T300RS GT with custom shifter (non-Thrustmaster) and I'm also revisiting older games to find something fun. Now I got why I couldn't make myself fully enjoy Snowrunner. Mudrunner is so much fun in contrast to its sequel. Arguably, it even looks better with moody, dark style - so different than what Snowrunner serves. But importantly, in Mudrunner you can fully use a steering wheel with a clutch and H-shifter and it is awesome! While in Snowrunner it seems to be a pointless struggle to set up your steering wheel, in Mudrunner I actually can do more and much faster (I have set up reverse where usually I have 1st gear and 1st gear is in place of usual 2nd - that makes getting out of mud so much easier than shifting the virtual gearbox with use of gamepad). I recommend setting up racing wheel buttons to resemble default controller setup - this way it is fluent for seasoned gamepad player to start using steering wheel with this game. And to finally put Snowrunner in its place, I have to say that in this game I really feel that my controller (regardless if it is gamepad or steering wheel) is connected to vehicle I drive. I feel immediate throttle response, I need to be careful with clutch and gears - otherwise I will damage the vehicle. In Snowrunner it all feels detached, just like I was steering the driver inside vehicle instead of vehicle itself.

While away the hours as you pointlessly move wood from one place to another. Feel the agony of tipping over, running out of fuel, or smashing a rock and totally immobilising your vehicle moments from the lumber mill, or just keep it simple and dig yourself a nice swampy hole to get stuck in. Fear not! Winch mechanics allow you to harass nearby trees and you can always send another truck to also get stuck - oops, I mean pull out the first one. 

MudRunner is all about the journey, even though you spend most of your time dreaming to just magically show up at the destination. Try to make a shortcut and watch your an asthmatic truck get punished severely by bogs, lakes and big ol' trees. 

Enjoy slow-paced, action-less game play? Think yourself a bit of a lumber freak? MudRunner is the perfect way for you to pretend your evening has been semi-productive, simply by shifting digital wood from one box to the next!

Incredibly fun, solo or multiplayer. The Physics in this game are unlike anything else I've played, and the realism and immersion is something I absolutely love.
Each of the maps in campaign mode are completely different to each other, and you have to approach each one differently.
Controls wise, it's relatively easy to learn, and comparability with controllers or steering wheels is REALLY nice.
The models for this game is something that I personally absolutely LOVE, you feel incredibly powerful driving some of the trucks in this game, and they each react and drive differently.

I do wish there was more variety on mission objectives, every map has the same "Deliver X from Point A to Point B" type of objective.

8.5/10 Pick it up on sale, for sure.

I like it a lot. You have to have a lot of patience because for obvious reasons it's a very slow-paced game.

It was a bit difficult at start, but got progressively easier, for example loading manually logs takes a bit of practicing with a crane.

While it is playable using a keyboard and mice, a wheel set with pedals is a must, especially when playing maps on hardcore difficulty.

Some negatives:
Vehicles have "side mirrors" that don't reflect anything. Just a slab of rectangular metal.
No rain at all
Background music has like ~10 tracks and since each map is pretty long, the looping music will become annoying real quick. I have disabled ingame music.

This is a tough one for me to review.  Overall it's a great game.  Just look at my hours.  But Spintires has a more advanced tire physics model and more up-to-date graphics, though I prefer MudRunner for the American content which Spintires doesn't have.  Unfortunately Saber seems to think Spintires belongs to them as well and they are engaged in a long-running legal battle with the developers of Spintires which has forced the game off the Steam store.  And that sucks for us players because now we are stuck with fewer choices (SnowRunner is a poor sequel with crappy sounds, controls and terrain collision).

So MudRunner is a good game but made by a company with some shady tactics.

MUDRUNNER

Steam has clocked me well below my in-game time, I completed about 1 hour or so.

Additionally in all my years of trying new genres of games I have been reluctant to try These types of Sims, I have no experience with trying similar titles to this.

So, let's have a look at the reasons for me not recommending this game, first off.. its pretty ugly looking, the in cab view looks PS2 and the general camera angles are annoying, furthermore i have a truck, I have driven a skidsteer and have experience driving a old 1980s large logging truck before, right through the woods at my cousins sawmill / farm property, we occasionally drove in swampier parts with little ease, big mudders just ripped on through with ease.

No my biggest complaint is the controls, everything feels floaty, punishing you for going to fast... even though the 80s f150 I used can easily knockout some of the dirt trails at 70 or 80kms an hour... anything above walking speed and you fishtail like crazy, you get stuck in knee high water easily and takes forever to get anywhere... have the devs never gone mudding before?

The missions seem repetitive and boring overall, the goals make you go back and fourth... honestly not very fun and kinda puts me to sleep. The missions also give little help, you must figure stuff out on your own which I am ok with.

Good trucking music would have helped quite a bit as well.

I know I only completed an hour and I am sure it will get better but I am not going to spin my tires and wait to find out.

Not recommended, not true to the simulation it is trying to portray.

They nailed it for realism with the mud. Personally I 4x4 throughout my teens and twenties, having always owned a 4x4 truck. Only for small gaps of time did I only own a car, but even then I would somehow found myself on a dirty/muddy trail, acting as though it were a lifted up pickup truck. That being said...I know the limitations of a road legal pickup, hence why you see so many obscure old school trucks and giant semi truck looking dinosaurs of vehicles. That's because these are the actual off-road units that could achieve what they do in this game. A ford f150 or 250/350 or a chevy 1500-3500, would be so stuck and buried almost instantaneously on these levels it would blow your mind. Thank you creators for making such an incredible and realistic sandbox style game for me to re-live my earlier years, and feel the nostalgia of getting so hung up in mud :P The only realism point you seemed to not include (thankfully) was the on foot transit between truck and winch-point, then back...lol that was always hell especially in places this game takes you, I think about it every  time I have to winch...Gawd I'm glad this is a video game lmfao.

So, I firstly played this game on Epic Games when it was given for free. I really liked. Then, after some time I bought it on Nintendo Switch. Honestly, the fps drops was annoying, so after some more  time, I bought it on Steam.

This game is a sandbox, where your main task is to deliver logs to lumber mill. It might sound easy at first, but believe me, on the way to the lumber mill, your truck will run out of fuel, flip and might even get so damaged, that you would need to repair it! The base game is based in Russia, but if you buy the "American Wilds" expansion for a few bucks more, you'll get the pleasure to ride on American roads.

Russian vehicles have modified front grills and made up names due to copyright reasons, but all of the American vehicles have the real appearance.

The grapchics are quite unique, but and awesome. The mud physics are really good too.

This game has an amazing community, with tons of modders, so if you get bored of the base game, you will find a ton of mods to make it intresting. Also, there is multiplayer.

So, I recommend you to try this game out, if you like cars, trucks or offroading, I think you'll find this game pleasent. 10/10.

[hr][/hr][h2] üéÆGameplay: [/h2][hr][/hr]
MudRunner is an off-road simulation game that mostly focuses around exploring. There is different maps and locations to explore. With the game's realistic physics engine, you can maneuver a vehicle through mud and raging rivers that realistically react to your weight and movement in an immersive sandbox environment. You get stuck much easier when you carry heavier cargo. The mud and train behave just as you would expect them to behave in real life. You must plan your route based on your cargo. 
MudRunner requires you to carry logs to a destination without damaging the car and without wasting fuel because that could leave you out of fuel in the middle of nowhere. In that case, your friend might be able to help you, since this game is playable in solo and cooperative multiplayer with up to 4 players. You need to complete your objective and deliverables in extreme weather conditions within wild, untamed landscapes in dynamic day-night cycles, driving powerful vehicles each with their own features and accessories.
As I said, your task is to deliver logs, and you do that only using a compass and a map that is yet to be discoverable at the beginning. As you drive around on the map, it will be discovered. On the map are small watchtowers. If you drive to one of the watchtowers, a large section of the map becomes visible for you. You will need to get the logs at the log station and also visit the fuel station after you have driven some distance.
In order to complete the map, you need to deliver a total of 8 log points. Your vehicle's attachments will have to be modified according to the size of the cargo you will be picking up. As an example, if you take a particular attachment you can only take 4 log points, and if you are playing alone you must deliver twice. You might not be able to take a large attachment on your vehicle because that would make it too heavy.
You must be picky about the vehicles you take. On some maps, you can drive on roads, while on others, you'll only find mud trails and challenging trains. 
Getting a high vehicle is important when crossing rivers so your engine doesn't stall. If you are not sure if you can cross a river, you can change vehicles in game. They are vehicles that you need to discover in order to be able to change into them in the game. The vehicles you discover can then be used on other maps too.
In the case where you or a friend gets stuck there is a winch that can be used to help, whereas if you aren't playing with a friend you can use your own winch. 
If you like variety, you can also find some good DLCs in the game.

[hr][/hr][h2] üí≠Final Thoughts: [/h2][hr][/hr]
The game MudRunner is one of the most frustrating I have ever played, designed to be frustrating. It's designed to thwart your progress and frustrate you, but there is some satisfaction in overcoming these challenges. The game is very good at burning time, so I would recommend it to a person who likes to take things easy and want some challenge at the same time.

Rating: 6/10 

Reviewed By: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198374140128/][b]Magnus[b]

Mudrunner is a great logistics game and a hell of a time with some friends and some drinks, but it can be a painfully slow and repetitive burn.

The game isn't for me, and I don't intend to boot it up again. But I encourage anyone looking at this game to check out videos and give it a try, because I know lots of people will love what this game can give you.

I am a 45 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single Mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I bought this game on sale and booted it up, didn't really like what I saw despite some reviews that gave it a positive spin, then forgot to completely shut the game down before taking an important phone call. 2 hours later, I now own a game I can't return because I went 10 minutes over the 2-hour cut off, all from sitting in a menu (I'm still mad at myself). I decided to make the best of it and give the game an honest try. I have just under 6 hours now. 4 hours is all I needed to understand that I screwed myself and now own a game I really don't like. The driving is janky, the mud is a bit much - like, I get that this is the point of the game, but it isn't a FUN point - and the game play is... boring. But it isn't even a good "unwind after work game" because of the jankiness and the ridiculous mud patches. I even watched a bunch of YouTube videos to see if I was driving wrong or not understanding any features. No, I get HOW to play the game it seems. It just isn't fun. 

I'm glad people out there like it. Me? I see nothing really redeeming about the game. Worst $10 I ever spent to stare at a menu in order to get stuck with a game I absolutely hate.

Looking at the global gameplay stats for this game reveals that the most commonly attained achievement is something only 45% of players have done.  I take that as 55% of people got bored with this game on the first mission and never came back.

That's because this game gets real old, real fast.  Constantly fighting the terrain to deliver the same stuff over the same roads in the same vehicle very quickly becomes a chore and stops being fun.  Your vehicle constantly yeeting itself in random directions, even on smooth paved surfaces, demands your full attention on every inch of a delivery.   There's no zen or relaxation you might in x Truck Simulator or other sim games that let you mentally check out and do tasks repeatedly.  And there's no real payoff or gratifying progression you'd expect from giving such attention and effort to a game.  It's like pouring your effort into a void that doesn't know you exist.

[b]MudRunner[/b] is a game about traversing through the heavily muddy terrain of Siberia while also delivering materials such as logs.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
- The game gives off the post soviet vibes really well
- The game looks really good and the physics of the environment are insanely good
- Driving feels great, but it takes a little getting use to
- Up to 4 player coop
- Challenge gamemode
- 9 Maps
- Steam trading cards, achievements etc.

[b][u]Neutral:[/u][/b]
- Not a huge variety in vehicles, and most of them aren't even that useful

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- You only deliver logs, nothing else
- The hand of your truck driver goes through the wheel which irritates me in first person view
- In multiplayer, you cannot see the other player's truck light nor see a driver in their trucks which ruins immersion

[b]7.5/10[/b] It's a good simulation game, but playing it in coop and the lack of variety kills the immersion the game could offer.

ORIGINAL REVIEW HERE: 

Wasn't a fan of the unrealistic way things handle. I have never seen a car scrape the side of a guardrail and have it's engine completely shot. It's a hard game, and I don't mind that, just save yourself the hassle of really wonky controls if you get upset easy. Thought this would suit my car needs but I guess not.


UPDATED REVIEW:

I have revisited the game. I saw it was on sale and decided to pick it up again. I misjudged the game a lot. There are still a lot of issues but those issues are what make the game somewhat charming now.

My largest issues are the unrealistic damage and inability for vehicles to drive correctly on smooth terrain. Driving a truck across pavement is about like controlling a car on ice. It's clunky and feels awful (this is more prominent in the American Wilds DLC).

However, the game has a strategy, and when I originally bought this, I was not looking to play a strategy sandbox. This game requires careful learning and strategic driving to make things work. It's quite cathartic when you get the hang of it.

Overall, the game is a good game for strategic driving sim fans. Still avoid if you get angry super easily.

The realism is both refreshing AND frustrating. If you enjoy problem solving and don't mind a slight time dedication, this game is for you! trust me when I say it, when you get stuck, you're STUCK, but with how realistic it feels, once you finally get out you're left with the feeling of "I did that" and very few games these days accomplish that sensation as well as Mud Runner.

Let's just say I've got 66 hrs in Spintires and 22 hrs in Mudrunners so far.  I'm not even a "car or truck" kind of guy.  It's just one of those kinds of games.  Just a little history from my understanding of this game.  I played the original Spintires when it came out and it was great too.  However, I think the developer had issues with the publisher and things couldn't get done correctly.  Such as updates and additions to the game in timely matters, etc.  So the quality of the game in the developer's and the eyes of the fans suffered, at no fault of the developer.  So think of Mudrunners as not a remaster of Spintires but what the developer wanted Spintires to be, to begin with.  It is Spintires Complete if you will.  This game is simple yet complex in its own limitations.  It is a simulation game.  You log to some extent.  It is mainly an off-road get stuck in the mud game.  It is depicted to be set in the Russian woods in various remote areas.  Which is really cool and kind of creepy. 
 Real-world physics applies to what it would be like to try and do this.  This game is addicting and fun to play in long segments and you keep wanting to come back to it.  I would like to see the addition of wildlife added to the game.  Things like Deer, bears, Alligators, and Rabbits.  Having them roaming around and being startled by your vehicles would be added to the environments of the game I think.  Great game and I am glad for the developer that it has carried on to the now MUDRUNNERS!

It's 2022 and I own SnowRunner, yet somehow I keep coming back to this game. There's a lot going for SnowRunner in terms of unlockables and progression, bigger maps and more objectives. But it also feels dumbed down. Console-ified.

Shifting gears is way more satisfying in MudRunner. Off-roading more real. Graphics are grittier.

There isn't a ton of content that comes with MudRunner (especially compared to SnowRunner). But that's OK. The best maps are actually fan created. And there are a lot of them. Start with anything by dmitriy1815 on the Steam workshop.

[h1]Gameplay Overview[/h1]

Since MudrRunner operates in an off-roading genre of its own, you might not know what to expect from the game.

There aren't really any rules other than the stated objective (deliver logs to the logmill), but each mission usually involves 3 distinct phases:

[olist]
[*]Exploration - using a scouting vehicle to find most/all the watchtowers in order to reveal the map, to help with the next phase...
[*]Logistics - there are various unlockables around the map (vehicles, garages) that will help you logistically with the next phase; also putting vehicles like fully-fueled tankers at strategic points so you can refuel
[*]Delivery - you need to retrieve logs from one of the sources around the map and bring them to each of the log mills on the map (usually easier said than done)
[/olist]

The challenge comes from the unpredictable terrain. It's going to get your vehicle stuck, burn through your fuel, and provide plenty of opportunities to roll your vehicle or get swept away in the the currents.

What you should know is that you're going to face most of these challenges at 3MPH. Like you could walk across the map faster than you'll be able to drive, if that was an option (it isn't). This is going to turn off many people. But if you can get past it, you'll find a meditative, zen-like experience. There's a reason people put 100s of hours into playing this game.

When you park the truck next to the logging and go work your way with the crane - both the truck menu and the logging's gets above one another and of everything else, all while the crane mixes it up - you eventually get crazy trying to organize everything because the information overloads, not even the mouse cursor can help you, not really and it is just chaotic. Fine to endure for an hour, but not to complete the game. Not sure if the GUI is only faulty in that situation, as the crazy camera won't cooperate when you need either.

Not intuitive as it should - at all. It has gotten really tiresome to work around, because it never memorizes the zoom you previously left it over - it does memorize the position but the zoom is irritating, it never gets right which is a shame for a game like this, functionalities of it does not fully attend the game. The orbiting is so clumsy and blocky, so insufficient you can barely aim to exactly where you need. In the end of the day, these things won't really act against the majority of players because they don't seem to go hardcore as the game demands... and that's convenient for the game. If you go take a look, a lot of us already owns and plays the game and that's really cool. But simple challenges such as towing a truck out of water, barely hits half of the total MudRunner gamer population. Some challenges such "Caravan", driving two trucks with logs barely hits 8% of us, which is absurd, given it is literally the first real tactical objective in the game.

[h1]Pros - the reason I give this a positive score[/h1]

[list][*]Incredible attention to outside detail, both audible and visual, its aging really well.

[*]Impressive realistic physics. I even think they had to downplay it to some extent.

[*]Hardcore mode and its challenges can make you sweat for real, like a real damn job.

[*]Playing with friends you know for team work is fun, an excellent time killer.[/list]

[h1]Cons - Sorry to disappoint but hat's the reality[/h1]

[list][*]The map has a parasitic prompt that only exists to be irritating.[/list]

Once you click the path you want on the map and connect the gps web, a small box written "ok" shows up with the distance you just clicked. But when you need to click again somewhere near, the damn prompt remains above it and you can't work the details. Unless you rotate or orbit the camera around the map, so the prompt gets out of the way.

[list][*]Hardcore mode lacks realistic approach on the winch, because the tool is just too easy to use and to connect to everything.

[*]There is no side mirrors to reflect things from 1st person, say like Euro Truck Sim has, forcing you to frequently swap into third person since the window won't always work.

[*]Camera needs more freedom and does not memorize previous zoom. [/list]

Even with the option off, it stills autocenter when using 1st person. Anchoring third person camera to specific heights or sides is very primitive for such high-quality game. It is like trying to fit a Bettle's engine into a Ferrari. Imagine the sound of that.

[list][*]Menu navigation is confusing and can super impose other things. It can get nasty in late game chaos. It is easier to tolerate it than the camera.

[*]Truck's cockpit needs the same attention to detail than the rest of the graphics. You don't see real controls in the panels, it is simulated with the interface itself (speedometer etc.)[/list]

When water is everywhere, nothing gets through inside. There is no way to wipe the windshields as I'm aware of and it takes some time for mud and water to disappear. In ancient times, it was mandatory for every vehicle simulator to be accurate with the cockipit camera. Speedometer, buttons, valves, gears, alert leds etc but there is none visible. Only the rarest simulators keep with that natural tradition nowadays.

[h1]Final Score edited: 7.0/10[/h1]

steam has me hostage

I love playing driving sims on my rig, and I also love playing more arcady racing games on gamepad. I also love driving trucks and equipment where you can use all of the utilities and tow trailers and stuff. 

I was really excited about this game because, on paper, it checks a lot of my boxes. In practice, however, it was a really bad experience. This is mostly due to unintuitive controls and mechanics.


With a steering wheel and pedals:

It typically feels best to use this setup with cockpit view, but in this game mirrors don't work, so you have no way of seeing your trailer or anything behind you on the right side(you can stick your head out the driver's side window to at least see the left side) unless you switch to an aerial view, but the game specifically gives you challenges to stay in cockpit view while you have a trailer attached, so by going into third person you fail those challenges. 

Furthermore, as with any driving game on wheel and pedals, the experience just kinda sucks without VR, because even if the mirrors DID work, it's really not fun to have to reach up to the mouse, unlock freeview and mouse around just to see the whole road in front of you. Needs VR to be a fun driving sim. Would also need a total rework of the controls for hitching trailers and using the winch and stuff since that's all done in this weird advanced mode menu that feels very poop. Also, force feedback is so weak that a lot of people are reporting that it doesn't work. It does work, but it's so faint that you have to close your eyes and become one with the force to feel it's existence. 


With a gamepad:

A little bit better since you can at least use the right joystick to more conveniently look around, but the steering is so very not good. This is mostly just an inherent drawback of steering a big truck with a joystick, but it takes forever for the wheels to turn, and by the time they get pointed in the right direction you're facing the wrong way. There's another "je ne sais quoi" to the steering that makes it feel insanely disconnected. I don't know what it is or how to describe it. The obvious solution to this is to use a steering wheel so that you're directly linked to the orientation of the tires, but as stated above it's a bad time. 

Not sure what everybody else sees in this game, but as a driving sim enthusiast, I really found it to be quite poop. Unfortunately not even worth the 4 euros I paid for it on sale. Hence the refund.

TL;DR: poop


Edit: Also I have no idea why but the first time I started up the engine, without moving an inch, I got an achievement for driving 200 meters with the parking brake engaged and another achievement for driving a total of 100 kilometers. I'm mainly sharing this so that you(yes you) don't look at my achievements, see the handbrake achievement, and think "well this guy's a dumb nutsack so who cares what he thinks."

I thought this game was hard, and then I played Snowrunner. The two games are arguably quite similar with Snowrunner being much more user-friendly w/much more surface level features and Mudrunner being the more difficult, more simulator-driven game. But the reality is that the maps in Mudrunner are only a fraction of the size of the maps in Snowrunner with the only tasks in Mudrunner being delivering logs, whereas Snowrunner has a massive collection of things that get delivered. For the time that it was released, Mudrunner was an awesome title that built upon the success of the original Spintires game. The reality is that now in 2022, Snowrunner has completely superseded Mudrunner and this game is much less of a good buy. If you can catch it on sale, by all means it is a solid game with decent driving mechanics, bland but passable graphics, and unmemorable sound design. There is plenty of mud to get stuck in and birds to scare away with your horn. If you have the money though, just pick up Snowrunner.

MudRunner does one thing, and it does it very well. You have a truck, and you drive it in mud.

It's a fun way to kill time if you want some no-thinky entertainment. The trucks feel nice to drive - there's a very satisfying sense of weight to movement, and finally un-sticking a truck out of a muddy spot is rewarding every time. There's not really much else to it, and that's for the best. SnowRunner shows us what happens when you try to cram too many features into a game like this, and if you ask me, MudRunner's minimalist approach ended up a lot better.

PROS:
The physics in driving the trucks is simulated very well. When you're driving through a big patch of mud, it really feels realistic to what driving the truck through that would feel. The landscapes are simulated very well, every little bit has massive attention to detail, and the graphics are pretty good, especially considering this game came out several years ago. I also like it because it can run on most any PC, it is not a very demanding game. 

CONS: 
I think many of the missions get too repetitive. This is my biggest complaint about the game. Some missions are interesting for the first half hour while you're driving around trying to get to the watch points, but then once you get to the delivery stages of the missions, they make you deliver an unreasonable amount of logs back and forth, miles at a time over the same terrain, which sometimes is even over a boring road. This just feels like the developer trying to get a few more hours out of the game, which they don't need to do since the game already has a lot of content.

VERDICT: 
Very good game, some great simulation, beautiful, muddy landscapes, just a little repetitive at times.

I still have yet to enjoy a single moment. WTF is this? Mental Breakdown simulator? Run-Out-Of-Gas-In-The-Woods simulator? My shit keeps getting stuck. Every piece of geometry in this entire fucking game is made of blended up sumo wrestlers. You'll be driving through what is textured to look like solid ground, as your car sinks into it like it's fucking quicksand. So... why can't I stop playing?

From a broad view, the hostility of the environment makes you fall in love with literally anything that works. The first time I successfully pulled myself out of a bog and back onto something resembling solid ground, I stood up out of my chair and did a little jig. My friends are getting used to me comparing anything reliable to the B-131 truck featured in this game.

Also, I don't know how they did it, but this game runs like a million dollars on my computer, so I really give the devs props for that.

* Disconnecting the winch is sometimes faster using the mouse rather than "L2-down-down-X" because if you have a car attached its "L2-down-down-right-X" and it gets messed up

MudRunner is probably the most frustrating game I have ever played. It is designed to be that way. In the game you spend a lot of time stuck or struggling to make progress or thwarted in achieving goals, but there is some satisfaction in overcoming these challenges. After the first job where you have to drive an articulated lorry to a parking place through a city, the second job has you driving completely off-road through a boggy, flooded forest to collect logs and deliver them to a lumber mill. What makes this difficult is the fact that apart from the mud, there are lots of obstacles like rocks, trees (obviously) and flooded ravines. The wilderness would be quite relaxing if it weren't for how stressful it is to navigate. I frequently ran out of fuel just short of my destination or rolled a truck in the middle of nowhere, so I spent far more time retrieving abandoned trailers or winching trucks back upright than actually delivering logs. I have to say that it has all been a lot of fun, but totally hectic and annoying at the same time.

I really wanted to like this game (and thought I would for its theme), but unfortunately I've always ended up with a headache after playing it. The graphics are nice, but everything seems somewhat blurred -- especially during sunshine. Maybe this is a stylistic decision or my bloom config, but my eyes somewhat can't get used to it. However, what I dislike the most is the camera. It's incredibly "twitchy" or "jumpy" for lack of a better word, especially when driving from the cabin. The POV resets or changes abruptly, and it always feels like I'm fighting the camera whether playing from 1st or 3rd person views. I also find the controls quite clunky overall, especially when playing with a gamepad, for which the game declares full support. For example, you have to go to the advanced menu every time you want to detach a winch, which is something you do like every 10 seconds. Some other actions are either very difficult (like setting map path markers) or straight up impossible (attaching a caravan) to do with the gamepad, making it feel like quite an afterthought.

MudRunner; Stuck in the Mud?

MudRunner is a open world experience, where plays can select their starting vehicle/s and explore a map where they may discover watchpoints, opening up a large area on the map, there for surveying at a birds eye view. The ultimate goal of the game is to either recover or collect different loads of logs and take them to lumber mills, often off the standard road and in the most inaccessible places possible. It is important to note that, while off-road driving is the huge selling point of this game, and it is the means to complete the objective, the game itself is, first and foremost, a logging simulator, or to concise it even more, being a delivery boy in one of the most difficult environments to drive in, swamps, bogs and mud.

Is the game fun and engaging? Well, yes and no. If you follow the objective, of which there are usually different ways of going about it, the game can be a variety of experiences, from fun and relaxing to tedious and stressful. If you are just in it to drive around, there are a vast variety of mods, most of which of high quality, all there to aid your efforts in creating the most botched drive you could ever imagine. Of course, this can get boring quickly, as is to be expected, so playing with friends is a must if you plan to only four wheel drive in this game. Personally, I find a mixture fun, but, it's important to remember, Logging is the game, off-road is just the means.
