Review No2: "So first things first: I orginally gave this game a positive review but since I learned about what went down between SPINTIRES and MUDRUNNER I had to change it.
The bottom line is: Unless you want to support thiefs: Go ahead and buy Spintires the Original Game instead of MUDRUNNER since it's basically the same game. (plus with the upcoming FREE Updates I reckon it will be much cooler than Mudrunner.)
Why thief you ask? Well I'll just paste a message of Zane Saxton in here which should clarify a lot of things:

"A message from Spintires Visionary, Zane Saxton

Dear Spintires Community,

I know how frustrating it‚Äôs been for you not hearing from me or receiving any updates for Spintires, and I‚Äôm sorry there‚Äôs been such a long delay.

I‚Äôm pleased to announce that we‚Äôre working on an update to Spintires, reinstating previously removed features, and adding new features and content. The first update is coming in April and will be followed by further regular updates, along with continued community support. 

Some of you have asked about the defamatory statements that appeared online after the extremely successful release of Spintires in June 2014 which led to false rumours, speculation and outright lies about Oovee Game Studios.

I‚Äôm not going to enter into a public mudslinging contest over this, but I do want to address some of the fallacies behind the original Spintires indie hit. 
  
#1 Pavel was underpaid / not paid by Oovee Game Studios
FALSE. Pavel was paid multimillion dollars by Oovee Game Studios for the work he did on Spintires per his contractual entitlement.

#2 Spintires is Pavel‚Äôs game
FALSE. Pavel assigned his rights in all his work to Oovee Game Studios. Pavel was the lead programmer and worked for Oovee Game Studios on the development of Spintires. 

#3 Pavel was the sole developer of Spintires
FALSE. Pavel was one of many people who contributed and worked on Spintires over the years to bring the ultimate off-road simulation experience to fans. 

#4 Oovee Game Studios was just the publisher
FALSE. Oovee Game Studios are the development studio and co-creators of Spintires. Our publisher was IMGN (although we did self-publish on Steam like you can publish your own book on Amazon).

#5 Oovee Game Studios abandoned the original Spintires game
FALSE. In June 2015 Saber Interactive approached Oovee Game Studios. This resulted in Oovee Game Studios granting certain rights in the game to Saber under a licence agreement. All rights in the game remained with Oovee. Pavel left Oovee Game Studios and went to work for Saber. 

Oovee Game Studios is currently working on updates to Spintires which it will release in the near future.

#6 Spintires is owned by Saber Interactive / Focus Home Interactive
FALSE. Oovee Game Studios are the sole owner of Spintires, including all code, visual aspects and assets, and the trademark.   

#7 Mudrunner / Mudrunner 2 are a different / separate games
FALSE. Spintires: Mudrunner, Spintires Mudrunner American Wilds, and Mudrunner 2 are all derivatives of the original Spintires game, as acknowledged by the community, who associate these games with the original Spintires game. 

What‚Äôs next for the Original Spintires game?

All this drama risks overshadowing a simple truth about the original Spintires game: it‚Äôs THE ultimate off-roading game. Putting all the drama to one side, the only real problem with the original Spintires game was its finishing touches. Starting with the update in April, and with many more to follow, this will be addressed, making Spintires a much more refined product than the first release, and as we continue to refine and develop Spintires moving forward we‚Äôll also be adding new content and features to bring you MASSIVE value. 

We have some exciting announcements to follow, and if you‚Äôd like the inside scoop on the latest developments of Spintires, then join our official Spintires Facebook Group 


Sincerely, 

Zane Saxton - Spintires Visionary

P.S. Let‚Äôs move forward and make the original Spintires game great again, just let me know in the comments below how you‚Äôd like to see the original Spintires game grow and evolve."

A nice bridge between the original Spintires and SnowRunner, MudRunner is fun but somewhat lacking. If you've played Spintires you've already seen A LOT of what is included here, from copied vehicles to several barely modified "new" maps...but it is fun to run through and unlock a bunch more achievements so there's that. If you've never played Spintires definitely get this, it has the spirit of the original minus all the legal drama but with added features like in-cab view.

Visually this looks nice, although the weird sepia tones on some maps are really overdone early in the morning. Controls are fine except for the crane operations, but they weren't that fluid on the original title either. Audio on MudRunner is hit and miss, the newer vehicles have suitable audio while the old stock ones are somewhat lackluster.

For you achievement hunters out there, the American Wilds DLC is indeed required to hit 100% on this title. You might have a bit of a time finding people for the multiplayer achievements as MudRunner never has been popular online compared to its namesake. You're looking at around 60 hours for completion provided you find other competent players.

This often goes on sale for very cheap, it's a solid buy on decent discount but old hands at this series may wish to skip it and go straight to SnowRunner.

If you enjoy driving big rigs and other heavy equipment across mostly loose terrain in a beatifully rendered countryside, with some light 4x4 exploration sprinkled in, and don't mind some repetitiveness and tedium on the side, this is definitely for you.

Despite not looking like one, and being third person view focused, I'd definitely classify this as a SIM, just because of the depth of the physics simulation. Terrain with varying degrees of softness, AWD/diff lock operation, great rigid body physics, like tire distortion, twisting chassis rails etc., simply every object interacts with every other object in the space as it would in real life.
The end result is it looks incredibly realistic, as you chug through twisty, cambered dirt and mud roads, over deep puddles and crests, hauling lumber, and your truck swings all sorts of directions.

A controller is highly recommended for the analog throttle! Layout is well-thought out.

To sum it up, pros:
- graphics 4/5
- physics 4/5
- detailed truck mechanics, including attachments
cons:
- bit repetitive, you either explore watchpoints, unlock garages, or haul lumber, just on a different map once one is complete
- no real replayablity

This game is so enjoyable!

I picked it up on a recent Steam sale for $3-4 and I'm glad that I did because, whilst there is no story to speak of, you effectively drive (or TRY to!) around a boggy marsh looking for logging camps where you can either chop the logs yourself (if you have the correct apparatus) or you can choose which type of load you want to carry (where different loads equal different vehicle behaviours.

As of writing this review, I tipped over and lost two loads (yes, that's a thing in this game!) and drove off a bridge without thinking.

No respawn in this, though if you are in SP, you can respawn the vehicle at the start, but if like me you tip over and lose your logs, you lose any progress you had with that delivery and have to start from scratch. So you NEED to be patient with this game!

The controls are standard WSAD with a few extra keys around those four to further improve/worsen your driving experience. I can't comment on if this can be used with a wheel, though if so you will be doing a lot and I mean a looooot of course correction.

I call this one more of a slow burner because driving in a bog on the first map is slow and tedious work, but if you don't want all your action in swoop after swoop of dramatic setpieces, then this might just be the game you're looking for!

Give it a shot, wait for a sale, or pick up it's successor Snow Runner. I haven't quite got the machine to handle that yet, hence why I bought this one.

Its a bit of an odd game. a truck sim where for some reason your always going through mud and getting stuck in it.
I suppose that's in the name.
The  issue I have is you can't do much to the truck to make you better at it.
There is no upgrades and customises. No real vehicle specs at all. I can't see how fast i'm going. I can't understand the weight ratio.... Its all a bit of a guess and.... hmm that looks heavy....
The quests seem pretty odd as well. so far the single player seems encompassed with logging.... just logging. and random exploring. Theirs no real story line in any way. no npcs to interact with. no radio to make it sound interesting at least.
The game can very quickly get quite boring. 
I'll keep playing to see how it might develop. But i'm not really seeing how i could recommend this to anyone.
I suppose I got this with the vision of driving the road of bones in Siberia. But it seems like endless logging and mud at the moment. With no gain or even economical factor.

Edit Update.
Played the game a little longer. The logging has become a little less tedious with the feature of being able to create road trains (two trucks chained together) so I don't feel like i'm doing the same route loads of times. Also it makes for an interesting challenge. But still with the constant logging. They need to change the challenge, maybe different type of cargo or more interesting main missions. 
Additional Update
I carried on playing. Its not bad when you read the online tech manual. You shouldn't need to for this sort of game especially just to find out the vehicle spec. 
the simulation parts of the game is only thing that kept me playing to be honest. I slowly figured out which vehicles to choose and how to drive. A strategy on how to use the vehicles. 
But the single player mode still seems to be centred around logging for some reason. Gets a bit tedious. 
I might play a bit more but i've finished most the game now. Wasn't overly satisfied but as said the simulation parts are fun. trudging through the mud and landscape and hill climbing.
Really good fun in multiplayer playing friends or family.

It's like a puzzle game where you drive a truck.
From exploring and planning the route, choosing and positioning the right trucks, down to passing a compligated road with the help of the winge - you keep solving puzzles to get to the destination as efficient as possible.
Finishing a complicated tour will feel very satisfying.
The downside is that once you solved the puzzle, rerunning the same tour 2-3 times to finish a map can feel quite dull, especially when moving slowly through the mud for half an hour.
The different maps, challenges and achievements present you with enough "puzzles" to enjoy dozens of hours. So in regard to the price, it's well worth it. (It took me relaxed 65 hours to "finish" the game - all maps on highest difficulty, all challenges, all single player achievements).
There is replay value in trying to solve the maps on different trucks, making it even more complicated.

Comparing it to ETS2 (where i came from gaming wise) it does not give you the same feeling of passing miles as the maps a very small, without any life and you only transport 1 good (logs).
On the other hand, organizing and planning the tours takes much more effort in Mudrunner than ETS2 and as such, was more enjoyable to me.

Tl:DR It's a driving game that's more about carefully navigating through harsh conditions than going fast

It's a VERY slow-paced game so if you're looking for a wild, balls-to-the-wall action off-roading game, you're definitely not going to get that here. This is more akin to off-roading or mudding where you're just trying not to get completely stuck or stranded somewhere and it's actually surprisingly relaxing and even meditative. There's also a surprising amount of tactics involved that makes the whole experience feel very rewarding and satisfying ("Okay, there's a big tree there so the ground right next to it should be pretty firm" "Alright, gravity pulls moisture downward so I'm gonna go as high up on this curved bank as I can." Things like that)

This game simulates the most challenging and interesting parts of operating heavy vehicles.  It is the opposite of the "Truck Simulator" games, which only simulate the most boring parts of truck driving.  As a truck driver I can recommend this game.  As a 4x4 owner, the sick feeling in the bottom of your stomach you get when you realise you are stuck and there is no easy way out is all too familiar.  Carelessness has serious consequences here.  If you go off the track and churn up the ground it stays churned up.  It would be nice to see some other challenges like loose rocky ground or a proper sand simulation.

[i]I actually used to drill holes into my toy trucks, tie ropes into the bumpers and pull them through the mud and puddles. Now I can do that inside in safety away from the dangers of the daystar.[/i]  

[b]Spintires: Mudrunner[/b] is a simulation-esque game of deep woods logging in Russia. (There is an American expansion where the pacing is a little different.) I say ‚Äú-esque‚Äù because there are a lot of things that'll suspend your disbelief. [list]
For instance:

[*] You can't leave any truck or vehicle. It'd have been nice to get out and walk around.

[*] The winches instantly attach to trees and other assorted things. I realize this is for convenience but I think it'd have been cool to be able to get out of the vehicle and attach the winch. Get back in the truck and and un-wedge yourself. 

[*] The attachments to the trucks appear out of thin air at garages. (Not on all maps, some maps don't even start you in a garage and just have garage trailers at the ready to unlock another garage located elsewhere.)

[*] The logs will instantly appear loaded in your truck at a log station. (This is only on casual mode. However, even in hardcore mode you can spawn any type of log in a kiosk. This requires loading but still remains removed from a ‚Äúsim‚Äù designation.)

[*] Unlocking garages is a weird game mechanic, I like that it extends the life of a single map but how did they build those buildings without equipment to fix and operate the vehicles that they were presumably put there to fix in the first place!?[/list]

[h1]I know I'm being nit-picky but that's because I love the game![/h1]
The game is pretty straightforward. You drive trucks. You grab lumber and then deliver it to lumber mills. Rinse and repeat. 

The game has a pretty nice difficulty curve. Casual mode has almost no consequence for any action. Any vehicle can be auto transported ie. teleported to a garage and repaired regardless of damaged incurred beforehand. Fuel consumption is lower and log stations remove the need for additional equipment like cranes and loaders. You'll learn the limits and benefits slowly through the progression of the maps and vehicles provided. Each map is essentially a sandbox anyways. But, you'll need to complete delivering 8 load points to however many lumber mills there are on the map to complete it and earn a ‚Äúprogression point‚Äù to unlock new maps and trucks. 

There are three types of logs, Short, medium and long. Worth 3, 4, 6 load points respectively. You'll notice that if you do the math, there is no way to actually deliver enough load points (without winching your truck to another one that's carrying a load) in one trip to a lumber mill regardless of what type of logs you bring. Making early maps seem to discourage carrying long logs. Which doesn't make a ton of sense seeing as to how they are the most difficult to actually pack and deliver creating an obvious difficulty increase. However, this all changes when you discover that the later maps have scavenge points. No stations or kiosks available. You'll have to deliver what the map gives you. Of course, there are ways to ‚Äúgame‚Äù the system. You can simply remove the logs from the spawn point and new logs of a potentially different length and new location will spawn. It's just supposed to be more fun and provide a bit more challenge. Try not to think about it too much despite my pedantic diatribe above. 

That being said, hardcore mode isn't terribly difficult either. (With the exception of the Deluge map, fuck that map. :D ) 

There are also challenges to do outside the sandbox maps. As well as multiplayer, you and your friends can take turns [strike]capsizing each other off of mountains[/strike] taking lumber to the mill or loading up at scavenge points. 

In addition to all of this, the game features steam workshop support filled with other trucks and new maps extending the game's life even further.

[h3]Into the mud![/h3]

MudRunner is a game that absolutely deserves more gamers, because it's absolutely excellent in its discipline! Unfortunately, it's anything but beginner-friendly, and that's regardless of the inherently difficult setting.

The game is not hectic, but some situations require attention and sensitivity. It's also great for chatting with a friend while pulling each other out of the mud or rumbling through the botany together with steel colossi! It's basically a sandbox in which you can try out a lot. However, you should give yourself some 'training time' - and you will be rewarded with many pleasant hours of fun!

The so-called tutorial does far too little to familiarize you with the core functions of the game, the menus and mod support are unwieldy, and this despite the fact that this game in particular thrives on it! Fortunately, MudRunner can rely on the Steam infrastructure - which is why this platform is actually a requirement for this game - yet it is anything but self-explanatory.

Even though the initial difficulties, I can warmly recommend the game and especially in cooperative mode it unfolds its true potential! I have already had so much fun with the game that it was important to me not to push other people in front of the many same problems I had to struggle with and thereby lose motivation - for this reason I have written a guide that should give some [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2374687991]start assistance[/url] as well.

Great game; the gameplay is slow but methodical. You have to keep your eyes on the road ahead of you, and not do anything stupid that'll flip your truck, and lose your load. Graphics are beautiful; I play on a potato computer with with intel hd graphics 3000, and the game still looks great and plays at a playable framerate, with graphics at the lowest setting. I bought the game with all the dlc, which was all worth it, and that was enough to keep me playing for about 15 hours. But what has really kept me around are the mods; you can easily download mods for the game, from the steam workshop. I've spent hours and hours just exploring new maps and driving new trucks, and I can't see myself stopping anytime soon. Great game to relax and burn through all your free time, though things can get really tense when driving on dangerous roads; overall 10/10 Soviet trucks are cool as heck.

i tried really hard to enjoy this game. but i got extremely fed up with how WEAK the trucks feel.

sure, there are positive points to this game like the genius shifting mechanic ( using controller ) and the very seemingly realistic simulation of differential lock and all wheel drive.

but in the end, i had to stop playing and delete the game because of these two reasons:
1. the engines of most trucks sound very strange and often sound like they are working very hard ( high RPM ) even though there is almost nothing happening, which adds to the frustration
2. most trucks feel extremely weak and slow. combine that with my previous complaint, and there you have very frustrating gameplay that becomes extremely irritating and tedious VERY quickly.
3. overall, it feels like the developers tried to make the game as hard as possible, but because of that they ruined the feel, in my opinion.

obviously, the above is subjective. but still an indication of what this game could be like for other players.

in short, the trucks feel completely weak, incapable of doing logging work. it does depend on which addons are installed, but all of the addons that actually get the level complete, make the trucks weak. and i was not even playing on hardcore mode.

the fuel usage is absolutely insane and it seems out of balance, especially on the really large C-class vehicle where the fuel usage is extreme even though the power is extremely low.

i would rather be forced to use less power and less throttle to make it through a level, rather than going extremely slow on full throttle, in 1+ gear and through light mud with differential lockers on and all-wheel-drive enabled.....

This game's physics, presentation, detail, and functionality is WAAAAAAAY better than Snowrunner.  Snowrunner itself would be far more enjoyable if it was available on STEAM.  Now all that needs to be done is re-create Snowrunner with Mudrunner's development team, use Mudrunner's physics engine, keep the progression and monetary systems, properly iron out the bugs and glitches, we'll have a game that surpasses both this game AND Snowrunner.  

I really can't emphasize enough how good the driving feels in this game after playing Snowrunner for months.  I was immediately delighted to drive vehicles that felt like they have weight, torque, ground pressure, WORKING suspension; also loving the OG water physics, mudding, climbing hills, not getting screwed over by a glitch every 10 minutes.  This game's got alot more subtle detail to the environment, engine sounds and models, vehicle addons that are unique to each vehicle and/ or country or origin.

Both games are good in their own respects.  But it seriously feels like Saber cheaped out on the development costs of this game.  Bring back the original dev team.  They did such a wonderful job.

Maybe it's the best off-road driving game in Steam.
But, as the previous one, it has many flaws

MudRunner improved a lot compared to Spintires 1, but also inherited many of his problems that still have no solution today.
My review was originally negative but I thought about it and I'm going to give it a chance. 
I hope it doesn't suffer the same fate as its predecessor. If you don't know what I'm talking about, Spintires 1 died due to conflicts between the publisher and developer, to know more you can see my other [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/263280/discussions/0/622954023416537887]review[/url]
Now in the hands of another company I hope it will continue to improve.

Although the game has a lot of good features, I'm going to focus on the negative ones, because some of them may be decisive whether to buy it or not for some people.


[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Amazing mud physics
    [*]Good graphics (*see Cons)
    [*]You really feel it better than the old Spintires.
    [*]Vehicles are beautiful
    [*]Awesome community of modders
    [*]Vehicle Workshop
    [*]Map Workshop
    [*]I really enjoy multiplayer with friends
    [*]You can save your progress in multiplayer
    [*]Camera control has improved a lot (*see Cons)
    [*]We have cockpit view! Although it needs refinement, its functional*
    [*]They add "challenges" like a tutorial, a little easy but I liked them.
[/list]


[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]The crane camera is horrible, worse than the previous one.
    [*]Gameplay is the same as before (carrying logs from one point to another). It can be repetitive for some players.
    [*]For me MudRunner is a lot easier than its predecessor
    [*]Some vehicles were removed and new ones added
    [*]Many addons of vehicles disappeared (chains for wheels, extra lights, spare wheel, etc)
    [*]Reverse lights do not work in some cases
    [*]You can't change the wheel types like in Spintires 1
    [*]Haven't played it with a steering wheel so I can't say much. With a controller, accessing the menu can be annoying
    [*]In the cockpit view it would be nice to actually see some reflexion on the mirrors.
    [*]Some achievements are bugged
[/list]

I know I said good graphics above but strangely enough MudRunner is awfully "gray", this was the biggest disappointment for me. The old Spintires wasn't very colorful but the saturation was a lot more acceptable. Here are some captures to compare:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301005166

Fortunately we can use ReShade to make it look better than ever, but that's not the point. The game should look good without doing anything. Here are some pictures to compare the vanilla game and with ReShade

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301008806

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301009114

With Reshade looks beautiful
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1319768985

[h1]Some suggestions for the developers:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Fix the color for the love of god
    [*]I want snow
    [*]Tracked vehicles
    [*]Since the game takes place in forests, it would be nice to see some wildlife or even other trucks like NPCs.
    [*]I'd like to be able to load logs from a pile and not have to spawn one or two at a time.
    [*]Be able to change the color of vehicles
    [*]Realistic damage mode, both aesthetic and operational (broken lights/mirrors/glass, scratches, flat tires, oil/water leaks, temperature level, etc)
[/list]

To conclude, despite everything above, this Spintires and the previous one are part of my favorite games and I hope to see it improve and with more content in the future.


***UPDATE*** 04.20.2019

Spintires 1 is back under development and they release a new update after 2 years.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ESPA√ëOL


Quizas es el mejor juego de conduccion offroad en Steam. Pero, como el anterior tiene varios defectos.
MudRunner mejoro bastante respecto de Spintires 1, pero heredo tambien algunos de sus problemas de base y que todavia no tienen solucion. 
Mi review originalmente era negativa pero lo pense y le voy a dar una oportunidad, espero que no sufra el mismo destino de su predecesor. Si no saben de lo que hablo, Spintires 1 murio por las peleas entre el editor y el desarrollador, para saber mas pueden ver mi otro [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/263280/discussions/0/622954023416537887]analisis[/url]
Ahora en manos de otra compa√±ia espero que siga mejorando.

A pesar de que el juego tiene muchisimos puntos a favor, me voy a centrar en los negativos por que algunos tal vez sean determinantes para decidir si comprarlo o no.

[h1] A favor: [/h1]

[list]
    [*]Excelentes fisicas
    [*]Buenos graficos* (leer mas abajo)
    [*]Realmente se siente una mejoria respecto del viejo Spintires*
    [*]Los vehiculos son hermosos
    [*]Excelente comunidad de modders
    [*]Workshop de Vehiculos
    [*]Workshop de Mapas
    [*]Se puede guardar el progreso en multijugador
    [*]Multijugador muy divertido con amigos
    [*]El control de la camara mejoro bastante
    [*]Tenemos vista de cabina! Aunque necesita refinamiento es funcional*
    [*]Pusieron "desafios", algo faciles pero me gustaron
[/list]  

[h1] En contra:[/h1]

[list]
    [*]La camara de la grua es horrible, peor que en el anterior
    [*]El gameplay es el mismo que antes, llevar troncos de un punto a otro. Puede ser repetitivo para algunos.
    [*]Para mi MudRunner es mucho mas facil que su predecesor
    [*]Se quitaron vehiculos y se a√±adieron otros
    [*]Desaparecieron muchos addons de vehiculos (cadenas para ruedas, luces extra, rueda de auxilio, etc)
    [*]Las luces de reversa no funcionan en algunos casos
    [*]Antes se podia cambiar los tipos de ruedas a usar
    [*]No lo he jugado con volante asi que no puedo hablar mucho pero he visto que tiene algunos problemas. Con control,     acceder al menu puede ser engorroso.
    [*]Algunos logros estan bugeados
    [*]En la vista de cabina seria bueno poder ver algo en los espejos
[/list]

Se que dije buenos graficos arriba pero curiosamente MudRunner es horriblemente "gris", esto es lo que mas me desiluciono. El viejo Spintires no era de lo mas colorido pero la saturacion del color era por mucho mas aceptable. Les dejo imagenes para comparar:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301005166

Afortunadamente podemos usar el programa ReShade para que se vea mejor que nunca, pero ese no es el punto. El juego deberia verse bien sin necesidad de esto. Les dejo imagenes para comparar el juego vainilla y con ReShade:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301008806

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1301009114

Con ReShade
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1319768985

[h1] Algunas sugerencias para los desarrolladores:[/h1]

[list]
    [*]Arreglen el color por el amor de dios
    [*]Queremos nieve
    [*]Vehiculos a oruga
    [*]Ya que el juego transcurre en bosques, seria bueno ver algo de vida salvaje o incluso otros camiones como NPCs
    [*]Me gustaria que se pueda cargar troncos de una pila y no tenerlos que hacerlos aparecer de a uno o dos
    [*]Poder cambiar el color de los vehiculos
    [*]Da√±o mas realistico, tanto estetico como de funcionamiento (luces/espejos/vidrios rotos, rayaduras, pinchaduras, perdidas de agua/aceite, nivel de temperatura)
[/list]


Para finalizar quiero decir que a pesar de todo, este Spintires y el anterior forman parte de mis juegos favoritos y espero verlo mejorar y con mas contenido en el futuro.

Mud simulation definitely makes driving around very interesting experience, and may cause _fun_.
Overall the vehicle simulation is very nice, and for the most parts it really works quite well.
Unfortunately the simulation epicness starts with the mud and stops with the tires for the most part as the simulation for rest of the drivetrain is quite horrible, to be frank.
This is probably due the "casual"-aspect of the game, as a realistic, manually handled, simulation would be very difficult to control without dedicated controllers. Alas, this results in (at least sound-wise) clutch constantly slipping, etc.
Thankfully that is not that much of a problem, given that most of the action happens in mud.

Definitely an entertaining simulation, and definitely sets itself apart on terrain / mud handling! But unfortunately for more hardcore people, it is somewhat casual-oriented, so it will fall a bit flat on the control side, although it certainly has much to offer, nevertheless.

If you google Spintires and read the Wiki, you will read the whole store about how the lead developer, Pavel Zagrebelny, accused Oovee of financial misconduct. He later started working for a different company and produced this almost identical, albeit inferior game with virtually the same name (Spintires: MudRunner) before changing the name. When I went to buy the China DLC for Spintires, I found that it was removed from Steam by an unidentified person from Russia for an unverified reason, probably as an exploit of Valve's automated DMCA  system. All of this is merely speculation, but I would put money on the fact that it was an action by the original developer of Spintires in a pathetic effort to boost sales for MudRunner. I own both games, but I will be removing MudRunner from my library.
bad game

Well, I had "fun". I'm still not sure what "fun" actually means in this context, but okay.

It's a weird phenomenon, these sims. But if your idea of fun is driving around for hours through mud and delivering wood to saw mills, then go grab it. The base game with the addon is okay price-wise, the expansion alone imho is not worth it though.

That is mainly, because some of the new vehicles make no sense on most other maps as they require roads to actually use ... and most maps simply do not have a big road network like the American Wilds maps. The 2 maps are also pretty boring comparatively...and even super easy. The saw mills are next to each other and connected by roads, and in one map you literally just have to drive from point A to point B via road.

Every map in the game follows the same procedure: get in your scout vehicle, drive to watch towers to make the map area visible, find some vehicles lying around, then find the for you easiest and quickest (or hardest and longest if you want) way to deliver wood from A to B or C to D and so on. The maps each have 2 saw mills that require 8 wood in total. There are also log stations, log posts and scavenge sites where you get the wood from. Log posts are self-filling, but usually the farthest away. For log posts you need a vehicle with a crane to load the logs yourself. Scavenge sites are the same but are exhausted after 1 use (but can respawn when another scavenge site gets exhausted), so these are the most tricky, but they only appear on DLC maps. Logs can be loaded in 2s, 3s, 4s or 6s, each requiring different truck addons, meaning trailers.

You can customize the vehicle loadout for each map if you want, but I just went with the base settings to keep the intended challenge. The mud is evil. Usually you have some tar roads somewhere, but mostly you'll be dealing with dirt roads of varying degrees of firmness as well as grass, hills and swamp areas. You will have to manage your fuel consumption and refuel trucks regularly, you will have to use the winch extensively and sooner or later one of your trucks will get stuck or fall over, and then you need to start a rescue mission.

My go to was usually to go to log stations with 2 big trucks in tow (you can do that via the winch in single player) ... or tow one of my less offroad savvy trucks with a proper offroad vehicle to the station, etc. You get the idea.

That's really all there is to it. Night time sucks, as is intended, and the physics are at times very wonky. Especially on actual roads the vehicles react like absolute crap. Nobody would be driving anymore if that were realistic. Damage is also weirdly calculated. Sometimes you take massive damage for prodding a tree at 1 mph, and at other times nothing happens. Small trees can even be driven over, while fucking BRANCHES on the road almost seem like an insurmountable object... even for bigger vehicles. 

There's also a few challenge missions which you can (and maybe even SHOULD do before attempting the actual game after the tutorial...they prepare you for all eventualities and are quite fun.)

But all in all it's still fun, but gets a bit drab after a while. There is only 1 real tileset and that is dreary green/brown, mixed with some sand and some rivers. Even in the American Wilds expansion. The sequel is supposed to have snow, but it's not on steam as to this day, sadly. But there's room for improvements and even some "fantastical" elements, like alien planets, lava, deserts, icy mountains. This game, however, is dead.
The "original" SpinTires is still being updated though, but apparently there was some sort of controversy, which I didn't exactly follow. Feature-wise this seems to be the better game though.

It's a puzzle game with trucks, logs and mud. I've enjoyed crawling on 1st gear thru mud to reach my goal, be it a garage, lumber mill, log kiosk or a fuel station, but the game is not for everyone. It takes a few hours for me to complete a single map, and a lot of that time passes in low grip conditions, managing the throttle and traction on a low speed so as to stay mobile through the mud and not get bogged down. If that sounds interesting to you, go for it! With DLCs there are a good number of maps and vehicles for you to try. Otherwise, stay away.

If I could give this game a "Yes & No" rating I would do it since there are so many downsides to what otherwise would be an interesting game.

It can give you a lot of joy but so far everything came with a big BUT:
The tutorialisation of many mechanics is lackluster, no FOV slider, the view distance is abysmal (Unless you tweak it yourself in the config files and through Reshade.me), Many mechanics just don't make ANY sense such that you just end your game session with a big SIGH. Examples:
- Loading more than 3 middle long logs in a carrier doesn't seem possible. Learned the hard way that after an hour of loading up a carrier with 18 middle logs only 3 actually loaded up & the rest was lost.
- The skidder cannot "load" middle length logs even though you can pull the carrier for it.
- Upon falling over you magically loose a log of 3 (Because rolling over isn't already frustrating enough)
- Fueling and repairing only works if you switch to external camera instead of cockpit.

That's just some of the mechanics that really aren't self explanatory and made me put away the controller in frustration a few times now. And that's a shame because otherwise this game provides a challenging playground that leaves a lot of room for adventures. But bad tutorialisation and boneheaded mechanics that just outright delete some of your work and effort drag down the experience.
Additionally many of the trucks aren't really distinct but rather modified versions sometimes literally just the color. So take the vehicle diversity with a grain of salt.
And on a side note: There is only one type of mission. Hauling logs from point A to point B. That's it. No repairing things, or building bridges nothing.

Now that this company has switched over to Epic it seems you also need an EPIC account to play multiplayer. Thanks Epic Games the embodiment of gaming industry cancer.

So if you are looking for a game just like this, you are willing to learn things the hard way and don't mind manually tweaking config files etc. this game is for you. Everyone else: Keep the money and buy something else.

This is another game where I totally underestimated the addictiveness factor. I mean, getting logs out of the forrest, how cool does that sound, right ? But as someone who has played racing games for practically as long as I own any kind of computer I wanted to try something else. 
The game looks really good. I don't own a high end machine but had no issues at all getting at least 60 fps which is totally ok for a game like this. The vehicles are looking even better than the world around them and the physic animation is crazy. The way the suspension moves is really great. What I didn't like is the dirt build-up on the tires, that looks not good at all. And I was dissapointed by the interior view. As I said, I come from racing sims and always play cockpit as it gives the most immersion. However, in this game you soon find out that the exterior view is the much better way to play as you have a much better understanding of where the tires of your truck are. And that can be very important. In the end I enjoyed driving around on the map in different trucks and getting to the various points more then actually delivering the wood.
I got about 70 hours out of this game playing all the original and DLC content in simulation mode. I did start a couple of levels more than once. But with the amount of mods you can get there are many more hours to be had. Plus you have a multiplayer modus where you can play with others and that sounds like fun, too. I played with a wheel but I don't think it is nessessary and a gamepad will suffice. My son even plays on the keyboard and says he has no problems. 
I do not regret buying this game and I am sure I will get lots more out of it.

First negative review I have left of a game as I can overlook many things, but this is a hot, steaming train wreck for online play.

I played the first Spintires game and greatly enjoyed the play style. It is a great change of pace compared to all the arcade racers and sims out there. Something that provides a technical challenge and makes you apply a different method of thinking to be successful. For the concept, I would award high marks. If only features in this version worked as well as it's predecessor.

This type of game is great for coop play, and that is why I bought it. With great expectations we launched the game only to not be able to connect. We are both Steam users, but found out we had to enable Epic crossplay to be able to join a lobby with each other regardless. Even then, it was about a 50/50 shot, as many times the game would show the player joining as ready/not ready, but did not display their name. When the game launched, they would be stuck in the lobby but would not join the game session. Several times the host could not even see their own ID in the lobby. How can you fail to join your own game? Ask Focus...

On the chance we were able to connect, the game ran well. Right up to the moment it didn't. A hard crash (usually from client but occasionally from server) would cause maps to be impossible to complete. Nothing like fighting for 15 minutes to winch a fully loaded truck through an obstacle and feeling accomplished only to crash 60 seconds later making that progress wasted. The worst part is you cannot resume the game in multiplayer as advertised. The host can continue, but we were unable to have anyone join that session. This renders multiplayer games solo after the inevitable crash.

Neither of us are low skill PC users. We investigated everything from disabling VPNs, port issues, stress testing hardware, and the only thing that was constantly not working was Mudrunner. I have 585 titles in my Steam library, and this is the first time I have pushed for a refund. It is that garbage... 

If you want a game for a solo experience, I am sure this will work just fine. If you want something to play with friends, I would recommend pretty much anything else.

I didnt really mean to write a review for this game but since a lot of people on the community hub complain i gotta write something to infrom new commers. 

People on the community hub say that the game crashes consantly and that the multiplayer doesnt work. Which is false. The game crashes only when cross-play is enabled(cross-play is needed for playing with Epic games not Xbox and Ps4). I had the same issue, dissabled cross-play and boom my game is no longer crashing. 
Basically if you want to play with a friend that has the game in epic games that will be impossible. Because the game not only crashes but it doesnt let you join the lobby again. So you have to start again and it crashes again. That makes it pointless in playing because you cant finish a map. But when you dissable cross-play everything works as intended. You can invite a friend and you can finish a map without problems. That is all the game works but the update with Epic Games kinda messed up stuff. 

If you are wondering if you should buy the game, or is it worth it. YES IT IS. There are tons of mods. Both good and not soo good. You can spend a lot of hours driving in the russian wilderness. It took me and my friend about 30 hours to complete the game without mods. WIth mods... its a different story. We ve been playing for hours and as you can see curently i have 156 hours and Im still not bored at all. The game has a good potential. Now imma try and rate some aspect os the game.

Rates:

Singleplayer: 8/10
Easy to explain. The maps you get for free are fun and all but its not worht playing alone. If you want i suggest brining some underpowerd mods and see how much u struggle. Its peacefull to play SP, but i personally don't recomed it. Also i dont recomed easy or casual mode it aint fun that way. Since there is no campaign or story its just driving and the main goal is to bring some logs to the lubmer mill thats all. But the roads and the mud that all over the map is what this makes this game MUDRUNNER.

Multiplayer: 9/10
As i said in SP always play on hard. Its funneir i will explain later.
Im giving it a 9 for a dumb reason. But first lets start with the goods and then with the bads. Its like SP, but on steroids. You have friends, or randomds. Up to 4 people(including you). That way everyone can do certain tasks. For example when me and my friends unlock the map. We have a person for everything. I usually load the trucks with the logs. Someone is driving the logs. Someone always brings fuel, and the last guy is always repair points. When the guys with fuel and repair are not needed they stay around the people who carry logs and escort them incase one of us messes up something like getting flipped over. It always fun. We try to race on the narrow roads we push each other and flip over. Then we try rescuing someone. The good things is that you can never run out of maps. There are A LOT of community maps and most of them are pretty well made and pretty creative. 
Everything is cool and all but the only down sides i can find are: You can't see other's headlights, and cant hear their engiens. Sometimes it just kills the immersion. The other bad thing is that you can't add more than 8 mods. But you always figure a way out. It just messes up with mod combos sometimes.

Graphics: 9/10
They are good enought not the best but still good. Only downside is that it aint as colorfull as Spintires. This one is a bit more grey-ish

Gameplay: 9/10
You have two main modes.
Singleplayer and Multiplayer.
I talked about them above. There is one more gamemode and its challanges. Its basically small maps where you have to do something they want you to do. For example: Load the truck with medium logs or unlock every watch point on the map. They aslo give achievments so if you want the game 100% completed yeah go for them other than that they are pointless in my opinion.

Controlls: 9/10
I've played the game with a keyboard, controller and a 180 degree wheel. And i never had problems. It works flawlessly. Only issue is when u change input mid game you have to restart.

DLC: 9/10
You have a much of DLC that are free and one expansion - American Wilds. I was never interested in so i never bought it. 

Fun: 10/10 
its awsome just buy it and play with friends. 

Price: 9/10 
Not to pricy, but i recom you to buy it on a discount. 

Overall: 9/10 
You wont regret the game if you like offroading and driving in the mud.

It's boring, but if you like the challenge of trying to traverse a muddy pit of a map and having to find a route that is fast but also doesn't make your truck flip, get stuck, and get lost. I would recommend using a controller or a wheel.

The game is fine, single player is even good. However, if you're buying this game to play with your friends you should not bother. There are a million different crashes and problems, with no good solutions anywhere on the web.

Playing with un-certified mods: crashes.
Playing with only certified mods: crashes.
Playing with no mods at all: crashes.

Try to resume the game that just crashed so you can continue your progress? Oh, sorry. Crashes.

Try to rejoin one of your friends after you crashed out of their game? Nope, sorry, not possible.

The best you can possibly hope for with multiplayer in this game is 30 minutes before the game crashes and you lose all of your progress and have to start over. Not to mention that the interface to invite friends is awful (un-ordered and offline/online are intermixed, friends who don't own the game show up), selecting mods is the same where nothing is alphabetized and no preset saving is possible.

Most of my own and my friends' play time in this game was spent troubleshooting and crashing.

If you want this for solo play, go for it. It's fun and good enough to be worth 10-15 bucks. But if you are going to try multiplayer, save your money and sanity and look elsewhere.

Was looking for something laid-back I could play outside of VR, this fit the bill nicely. Works perfectly fine with just a mouse and keyboard, though I suspect it might be more entertaining with a wheel and pedals. One thing to note, if you're not the patient type, this might not be the best fit. There are plenty of times where you're simply cruising down a muddy trail in low gear, occasionally adjusting your path to avoid a rock or something. On the flip side, there are some tense moments as well.

Risk vs reward plays an interesting role. Do you load up with a longer, heavier trailer for more points, but risk getting stuck? Or do you play it safe and make multiple runs with a smaller loadout? Opt for the shorter trail through deep mud, or go around the long way on pavement? Test your pickup's stability by heading straight up the side of the mountain, or go for the switchbacks?

This used to be one of my favorite games to play!  I loved playing for hours.  A few months ago, an update (around the time that mudrunner forced the "Epic Games" account merge" came out that, for me, makes this game a super pain in the ass rather than fun anymore.  I have no idea what happened to the physics or why they got changed, but now I am finding that I am having to winch myself every 5 feet which wasn't happening prior.  I even went back an played easy levels that I know I sailed right though and still find myself having to winch a ton.  The constant winching really makes this game no fun.  I understand that a level of difficulty makes this game fun and satisfying when you accomplish something after a few hours of work, but an easy level taking 4+ hours to complete is ridiculous. After playing for 49 Hours, I am probably going to just quit all together, which is sad because I really loved this game.

After much more time in the game, I have to retract my recommendation.

This game is immensely fun, but among its numerous design flaws, it has this one massive, crippling problem: very little content.

There are only a dozen-ish stock maps (if you got all the DLCs) to play, and after that, you have to either rely on community-created mod maps, or replay the few stock maps (which is not fun). Unfortunately, there isn't much for decent mods for this game(at least not that I've found so far). There are thousands of mod maps(across steam workshop and other mod websites), but very few of them are enjoyable enough to play, and I haven't found any enjoyable enough to finish. More then half of them are simply broken and can't be played because the creator never put in one or more of the basic, essential, necessary features that every map must have. I applaud the awesome players who have at least tried to contribute something to this game's fan community, but it hasn't come to any meaningful use.

I had to wait three years to get it on sale, and I guess I'm happy with my purchase (considering I got it 80% off, and it's intense fun at first), but the enjoyability of this game completely dies once you've done the few maps it is sold with.

The multiplayer feature is a mess that seems totally broken, and the forums are littered with angered players complaining that multiplayer is useless and needs to get fixed. To make matters worse, if you install a mod, the multiplayer screen just gives you an error saying 'mutiplayer and multiplayer achievements are disabled'. So, you can only play multiplayer with the stock content, which isn't worth the trouble because everyone has already done those few maps a million times.

The creators need to release a whole new maps pack, and add more capability and stability to their mod editor tool. And it needs to be a free expansion to make up for how tiny the stock content has been so far, not some purchasable DLC. I have all the DLCs and if they weren't so cheap in the big sale, I'd feel ripped off right now. If there was just more quality content, this would be a 9.5/10 game. With the content as it is... score is irrelevant, the game just doesn't count. There isn't enough to play here to be worth grading.

I came to MudRunner from mainly flying and racing sims, and more recently via ETS2 and ATS (which I love). I wanted to like this, and do enjoy the used-looking trucks (great) and the wild terrain. But ... the driving control implementation makes it virtually unplayable for me. 

I'm using a Logitech wheel and pedals and a Thrustmaster shifter, which the game sort-of recognises ... but only up to a point. If I try to allocate a wheel button to a control, it tells me I'm trying to reallocate the throttle control, which is of course a pedal ...??? Etc etc with trying to map the other controls.

The force feedback is either on - way too solid, very little feel - or off, with VERY light steering resulting.

The whole steering operation seems off - as though it's made for a gamepad, and operates in distinct digital steps, even when being run through an analogue wheel ... with what seems like a built-in delay as well, I spend the whole time heaving side to side on the wheel just trying to take a light jeep style vehicle down a straight section of tarmac road ... not enjoyable. A bit like trying to steer an ocean liner rather than a car ...

Add to that the seemingly VERY tight parking requirements, and it just became tedious for me. I tried the first (?) challenge, and quickly got the trailer to the desired location with all bonuses intact ... it then took me AGES to reverse park the trailer in the highlighted slot over a muddy (well, it is MudRunner!) swamp which played even more havoc with the steering. It stopped being an enjoyable challenge, and just became very tedious.

I couldn't believe that it was meant to work like this! I'd appreciate any help for setting up the controls better, if there is something different I can do.

I did want to try SnowRunner, but that's not yet on Steam. If / when it is I may try it, hoping that the controls implementation is better and more like 2020 than 1980 ... but I'll definitely keep my trial under two hours, and so leave open the option for a refund.

Wish I had picked it up in it's prime!!! Doesn't seem to be any servers running. But still a solid and enjoyable solo game. Workshop mods have some good trucks, extras and maps still. Over-all Idea= Logging in rough country in different countries. Lots of mud and water. You will get stuck. You will submerge your truck in rivers while trying not to get rolled and swept away. You have a winch. And can use other vehicles to winch/tow or fuel/repair. Find way-points, vehicles, and fill lumber-yard orders. All depends on your play style. If you are impatient and rush games.... then maybe not your thing here. If you can get behind the idea of the game already and enjoy trail running.... then you'll do fine and have fun. Only real complaint.....The damage needs to be more realistic. Would definitely be more fun with others.

Definitely a good looking game with a cool environment to explore but I'm not sold on the controls or the overall feel of the game. They somehow managed to make driving a truck more difficult than it is in real life. While on the pavement the vehicles are ridiculously slow and yet super hard to control. It's like you're driving on ice with square wheels with your speed governed to 30mph. Very strange. I would have refunded the game had I not forgotten that I purchased it. If you know nothing about how trucks handle and also have no clue about how transmissions work you'll probably like this game. But, as someone who has driven plenty of heavy equipment in the muck I must say; the people who talk about how realistic this game is have no idea what they're talking about.

Nice idea for a game, but really, have the devs ever even driven a real car: You can hardly move the car without 4x4 activated on asphalt! Seriously?! Oh and you're driving 20mph on asphalt, and you try to drive over some car size pool of light mud..yep, you get almost stuck in it as if it was glue.. I've seen better car interior graphics in the 80's. Sound department isn't any better either; you can hear the engine's idling sound in the background even when you accelerate..seriously, who thought this was a good idea? The maps are suppose to be vast...yeah right, takes about 10 minutes to drive around the whole map.. On the positive side, the graphics are otherwise bearable for a couple of years old game, and it's kinda cool how the mud splashes over car's surface. If on -50% something sale, then sure, buy this; it beats the original Test Drive..barely.

Okay, so I've played this for 45 minutes. Coming from racing games, I wasn't sure what to expect. After the tutorial, I skipped to the Challenges to learn more about the game. The first two were fine, basically slow paced fetch quests with interesting or silly and optional mini-achievements, such as scaring off 10 birds with your horn. The third challenge was, somehow even more simply, to climb a hill. Easy enough, right? No. You will slip. You will get stuck. You will watch, terrified, as your rear tire begins to droop over the edge of a cliff. You will turn on all wheel drive and pray to unknown gods. And you will plummet in a ball of fire to the game over screen, presented with the option of trying again. In my final attempt it took me four minutes to climb that hill, but they were some of the most information dense and engaging four minutes I've felt in a video game since... I don't know, ever. If you're afraid of driving on roads with unguarded cliffs to either side in real life, and looking for an easygoing thrill, you may have found it in an unexpected place with this game. Totally recommend it if you're looking for a different kind of fun.

Note - I got it on sale for five bucks, so my expectations weren't high. Now I can say I'd buy it at full price, too. I'm probably going to end up checking out their 2020 game, SnowRunner. I assume it's more of the same, and in a good way.

Honestly one of the most challenging driving sims I have ever come across. Very steep learning curve but man is it satisfying once you get the hang of it. Physics feel great and you can really feel the weight of every truck, attachment and trailer you have on your rig. Driving mechanics are raw, you're in control of your own fate; for better or worse. The color palette is a bit..drab? Sullen? I don't know, but some more colors/scenery wouldn't go amiss. But for sheer off-roading and challenge, this can't be beat. Not only that, but the addition of mods to this title really keep the lineup of trucks fresh!
This is what life is all about, dragging yourself forward in the mud.

At first glance, it's just another truck sim which takes place on muddy Russian / American landscapes. You will have to carry logs to log stations and such... it takes time and patience, skill if you are in hardcore mode. But that's not it about this game.

THE REAL PURPOSE of this game is to have one of the best off-road experience, using Steam Workshop mods. Workshop got all sorts of terrains, from rocky trail road to muddy trial course, and trucks, from small Suzuki Samurai trail truck to 8x8 trial trucks. I can assure that Mudrunner combined with really nice Workshop mods will give you one of the best offroading experience you can ever get playing a game.

Who knew that logging and moving loads to lumber mills would be so much fun. This game is overall pretty well done. The challenge is there and will require you to think before you act as getting stuck is fairly easy. The choice of vehicles is pretty good and you can feel the weight of those big trucks. Beware that big does not imply you will not get stuck but a good winch can help you out. Overall, performance on nvidia surround (supported right out of the box) is excellent with all the details to the max on a GTX 1070. The game is no overly demanding and the graphics are pretty good. If you want a change from high pace racing or action game, try this game. It is simple in its principle but will keep you busy for hours. Truly recommend this one to anybody while waiting for the Snow Runner on Steam.

As the story goes, this game was created originally as Spintires in 2014. This beautiful, full terrain-deformation trucking physics game was the first of its kind. Unfortunately, the publisher for Spintires thought it fit to release as basically an alpha version of the game, stopped payments and locked the original creator from ever updating the game again. Luckily, the game engine was so unique the original creator actually maintained copyrights for it and was thus able to find another publisher to give this beautiful game the proper release it deserved. Boy, does it deliver!

The improvements:
- I'm a huge fan of playing by controller, in the original there were quite a few things that were either way easier, or simply impossible to do without a mouse. Since then, the interface has been drastically updated to become fully accessible with controller input, and has never been easier to navigate!
- The vehicles. Some vehicles were either missing functionality or downright nonexistent in the previous game. It's nice to see more than just postwar Russian vehicles!
- The challenges. Sure, the mechanics here are fundamentally the same as Spintires, but there you basically had to learn everything on your own. The launch tutorial and the unique challenges ensure newcomers get a grip on the game before sending them out into the giant open-world playground that is MudRunner. And the additional objectives provide a lot of fun for returning players like myself!

If you haven't heard of this game until now, and driving through the wilderness, getting yourself stuck (and hopefully unstuck!) in the mud for countless hours while listening to a nice podcast in the background, this game or SnowRunner are just for you. If you own Spintires and wish it had a little more, or simply want a better, overall more stable and user-friendly experience that actually benefits the CREATOR for all their hard work they put into this gorgeous game, you should definitely check this one out!

Very satisfying game focused on picking up and delivering heavy, awkward loads in very marginal traction and balance conditions.  Accurate, fair physical model of suspension, drivetrain (2/4wd, diff locks), traction, and terrain.  Engine revs model leaves something to be desired, although I usually play in automatic or shift to +1 and leave the pedal to the metal.  +1 this game has a winch for god sake.  Highly recommend co-op with a friend, that combined with good community maps really expands this game beyond teaching yourself the tricks of the trade in 1-player.  Enjoy!

MudRunner is the great game, but a very large number of very unpleasant problems have not yet been fixed since spintires.

1. Minimizing a window or switching to another window leads to the kick off all players connected to you

2. Already many years have passed, but still not visible headlights, stop lights of other players, even sounds! This is not early access is not it? .... it feel like playing on silent movie. Mud, ditches, broken trees, not syncing at all!
I did not expect this from such a high-quality game ...

3. Was not the "transparent machine system" a temporary solution before normal co-op game mechanics will existed?
You cannot even attach a trailer to another player, and you can also drive through another player, all other player cars become transparent for you if there are no players in them at the moment.

4. Only one trailer can be attached, why not two or more?

5. Ability to install modules in the garage that do not make sense in the current configuration. For example, fire-safe exhaust in a configuration where it is not possible to install a fuel tank. and many others.

I really hope that MudRunner will develop further.

I got this game on 75% sale but I cannot say that I enjoy this game at all. The physics makes it very hard to drive the trucks. It is like more than 90% of the time you spend in this game you would have to constantly battling with trying to free the truck from stuck situation even from road surface that doesn't look muddy at all. 

So it's either the dirt road surface in this game doesn't looked like it should be or the trucks weigh ten times of the real world counterpart so the moment you step of the accelerator pedal the tire would sunk right away into the dirt. I have seen a lot of real world trucks driven through the surface that looks a lot more wet and muddy than the map I played in this game but they didn't struggle as much as I struggle trying to move even in a very small sized map of this game.

It would be more enjoyable if there is an option in the game that allow users to adjust the level of the mud physics. I was about to ask for refund when I play about 80 minutes but I thought to give this game another try before I ask for refund hence the 2 hours playtime. It's sad that I have to ask for refund because I actually like the idea of the game and enjoy off-road driving games. But MudRunner's mud physics and lack of an adjustable options for the mud physics in the game makes it way too hard for me to enjoy MudRunner.

If you like off-road driving games and enjoy spending few hours of your time in the mud trying to travel just for about 1 Km in the game then this game might be what you've been looking for.

But for me personally I would not recommending this game if you are looking for games that allows you to enjoy exploring the off-road world without the frustration of getting stuck at one point for few hours. Get SnowRunner instead. Too bad at the time I write this review Steam doesn't have SnowRunner yet, it will be great if I can purchase it in Steam too.

Would be an great game to have fun and mess around in but there's a couple of glaring issues I have revolving multiplayer.

You can't join a lobby mid-session - Why is this a thing? This is such an archaic way of playing multiplayer, It's pointless and kills multiplayer in my opinion.

On top of that, it only allows for 4 players at once in a multiplayer lobby. Why? Another thing that just doesn't make sense as the only objectives are gathering wood and dropping it off.

It would be nice to see more vehicles and more support for this game, the next game (snowrunner) is supposed to be quite a bit better. Still a fun game to play some time.

I thought it was Snowrunner. Its ok, but NOT Snowrunner. If you want the full game, buy Snowrunner. The people who helped develop Spintires and Mudrunner got shit on when they released Snowrunner on a different distribution site. If you dont mind any of that, then buy Snowrunner. 
If you like Snowrunner really well, then buy this afterward, maybe to get the full experience. This game (Mudrunner) is ....30% of what Snowrunner is. I asked for a refund soon after buying, soley because I thought it had a major bug. Turns out I was doing something wrong, so it didnt warrant a refund. Now if I want Snowrunner I have to dish out another 60 bucks on another website. I think I will wait and see what happens before that.
So.... to sum up. 
They started with Spintires, sold that until they figured the bugs out, and then....
Sold Mudrunner until they figured those bugs out, and then......
Sold Snowrunner, the finished game.

Would I recommend this game? Yeah, if you enjoy simulation driving games (not a racing sim but more utility-work driving sim) and enjoy the slow precise driving with the chance of getting stuck in mud, or the possibility of being swept away by river currents, then this is a game for you. 

Mudrunner is very similar to the previous game Spintires (not made by the same developer), however having briefly played Spintires. I can agree that this game is better looking and slightly better simulation wise. One slight disappointment was Mudrunner not having the ability to deflate wheels for traction (Spintires had this option on a few trucks). 

A couple features that Mudrunner has over Spintires is a first person camera and IMO a much better and quite frankly less painful to work with, third person camera system. The mud in Mudrunner is far easier to drive through than Spintires, maybe that's in the titles and I've just not noticed? :/

Mudrunners is certainly enjoyable with different maps to play and on different difficulties, and many trucks and cars to unlock too. Each map introduces new challenges and the chance to find new vehicles which you might have not unlocked. There is also a challenges page to attempt up to 9 challenges, each rated up to 3 stars. There is somewhat ~60 achievements to unlock, I have been grinding through most of them (some of which challenging) which adds to the things to do in this game.

One great thing about this game is its free DLC. As I write this there are 3 free DLCs and one half price (during a sale for Focus). I am yet to play the maps however I have used the vehicles from the free DLCs and think they are cool to have. In most cases these vehicles may not be an upgrade to the base game vehicles but they are nice to have.

I know a lot of gamers have a higher budget than me, but it's basically a paywall, it runs on weak PC's, it only needs 4 gigs of ram, but it costs SO MUCH. In terms of gameplay, I'm not in love with the logging aspect, but the physics are great and it runs almost at 60 frames on my 12 gigs of ram. If they lower the price by maybe 5$ ( either the DLC or main game) I would be much happier.

Very much the same game as Spintires, but with some more polish, more vehicles and new maps. It does have some bugs which I hope Snowrunner has corrected (mostly, headlights for other trucks do not show in multiplayer and there is no common terrain deformation), but nothing that prevents this from being an enjoyable game, also in multiplayer.

The series is, unfortunately, the only real off-road simulator with trucks that I have found. However, I adore it. The driving (with a wheel) feels about as you would hope when compared to the real thing (IIRC, it was a while ago). Not perfect, mind you, but it mostly has the weight it should. It does have occasional immersion-breaking physics, but mostly the package stays together well enough that it does not matter.
I would not mind if it would be even more unforgiving than it is, but it is a game and it might prevent normal people from enjoying it.

When playing alone it starts to lose it's appeal over time (i.e. when you have finished all the maps), but the challenges are a fun (albeit short) way to pass the time. 

With friends, at the other hand, it is always fun when you get a few friend together. It's also very easy to beat if everybody takes an OP machine, but forget those and do this instead:
- Take a shitty truck with no all-wheel-drive (B-130 is fine, albeit it lacks a crane so you need something for support)
- Restrain yourself from teleporting to garage (if not playing hardcore) and help other when you get stuck
- Use your favorite VOIP to talk with each other
- Take a sip of vodka
- Deliver the logs
- If it feels too easy, there is always a worse route to take
Remember, it's a Russian truck simulator. Losing is fun.

MudRunner is an adventurous truck driving simulator, and at times a crane simulator ~ and not far removed from being a lumberjack too.

While this game does have quite a learning curve, a good place to start is with the Challenge mode, which allows the player to learn about different aspects of the game (e.g. learning to drive through water and thick mud, loading logs with a crane, night driving, etc.) while doing missions - all with bonus objectives that make for even more of a challenge, and give the missions some replay value if these objectives haven't been achieved. The main way to play is single-player sandbox mode, where the player can play at their own pace, and drive freely around the map (though there are roadblocks for trucks in certain places when loaded full of timber, which can be inconvenient).

For the most part, this is a slow paced game (very slow, at times) that definitely requires patience (such as all the times you will get bogged, or while trying to reverse through the mud with a large trailer that just wants to jackknife), but the experience is gritty and adventurous, especially when going off-road in a largely untamed natural landscape.
Multiplayer is also available online, up to 4 players, though there's no guarantee that there will be other players ready to join you, unless you organize a few friends yourself.

No violence or themes, despite the game's rough appearance. Naturally vehicles can be crashed or flipped over (the driver never seems to get hurt, though). There is multiplayer chat as well, which parents will want to be aware of.

While this game is not for everybody, I'm happy to include it in the list.


***

EDIT: Game has been completely abandoned in favor of a "sequel" named Snowrunner, which has the bare minimum of new content because it exists solely to get Epic Games' money. Game breaking bugs were never fixed. New content was never added. That seems to be the M.O. with the developer 'Pavel' you might hear about. In the meantime, the game you want to buy is the original Spintires, which is being maintained and updated with new content all the time now.


Initial impressions are that this is worth getting whether you're new to the game or coming from the original Spintires. Other reviews have already summed up what's good and bad with the game, so I'll focus on what's different from the original. Mudrunner doesn't offer much more than some tweaks, a new internal camera option, and a promise of future content, but while the original Spintires was plagued with an inexperienced and stubborn publisher, this version has more going for it. I'll update this review as things go on.

Hopefully we'll get new maps and vehicles with updates, and hopefully better mod tools will come out. The problem with the old Spintires is that there was no official way to make modded maps, which is something that I think would add hundreds of hours to the game's enjoyment since having only six is very limiting.

One important thing to note is that unlike the original Spintires, this one has a progression system. You have to unlock things by playing the maps, which means you have to experience the new content first before you get to use the old goodies. I kind of like that, but I can see that rubbing people the wrong way. The problem with the vehicle options is that there's about eight trucks that're all identical to one another except for their tires or having differential lock or not. The old game just let you swap out tires on trucks, this one doesn't seem to let you do that. I prefer the old system, because I'd rather have three trucks on a map with options for them rather than nine trucks that're mostly useless and two that I can do things with because of their tires not being garbage. That's really my biggest complaint so far, unless I wanted to complain about spending $12. I'll complain about the money if I don't see any updates in the next couple of months.

A weirdly cathartic simulation game where you are a logger in [the muddiest area ever of] Eastern Europe.  

Gameplay loop revolves around driving trucks in a unexplored map, uncovering new areas, using a wench to pull out of being stuck, picking up logs and delivering them to the mill. The trick though is dealing with the terrain,  the mud,  fuel, and rivers.  Much of the game is switching from regular drive to 4 wheel drive and turning on and off diff lock as to conserve fuel but not get stuck. 

Pros:
- Weirdly relaxing. A really good "podcast" game.
- Multiple maps
- Steam workshop 
- Optional hardcore mode
- Challenges (like only drive in FPS, no damage, etc) are options
- Leave the game to play later? It picks up literally EXACTLY where you left off.

Cons
- Textures and texture pop-in are bad. You can mod textures.
- If you don't like these kinds of games this isn't going to change your mind

The advertising for this game does not represent the basic gist.  MudRunner is a logging simulator. You retrieve logs using trucks and various logging cranes in Russian wilderness in the 1960s.  The natural landscape is unknown to you and the usable vehicles are hidden.  You go through a process of adventure-and-discovery to find the vehicles and deploy them. 

Nothing in this game is scripted  as it is a simulator.  Crazy, unexpected events take place merely due to the laws of physics.   The decisions you make have consequences and there is no [i]Game Over[/i] here to save you. Any mistakes require recovery with ingenuity.  When trucks turn over they are stalled in distant forest. You must bring in larger trucks to perform  "heavy rescue"  with wenches.

NOTE: Ignore all of the issues surrounding the game's developers, in my opinion, this is a better version (though Spintires is the original and they are both basically the same game)

Robbaz got it right when he said the sequel (SnowRunners) is the ultimate Dad Simulator, this is the prototype Dad Simultor, in a good way.

The basic idea of the game is to "Scout" the map by driving through Fog of War to reach viewpoints, then using the biggest, baddest, dirtiest trucks you'll ever imagine, drag logs from the logging area to the log mill. This might not sounds like fun but let me tell you... it isn't. You'll get stuck in mud, drowned in rivers and fall down ravines. It's a game about patience and determination, zoning out until that sense of achievement when you finally deliver 10 tons of logs, then cry as you realise that you have to do it all again as the log mill wants more.

The graphics are good as well, and the physics engine when it first came out had never been seen before. The mud reacts in realistic ways (I'm guessing) and when you hit that tree driving 35km (this isn't a racing game) with a full log rack... you feel the impact.

I've been playing this game for years and even enjoyed the expansion (American Wilds) on Switch. It's my go to game when I need an hour away from the world, watching the sticky mud fly off my tires, as I drive a vehicle I'll probably never own, around a beautifully made up world.

I like it.
