Initially I didn't expect to like this game much. From watching videos it seemed like it might be a bit boring.
I decided, against my better judgement, to try it out anyway, and I'm really glad I did.
It's a nice change of pace from high octane FPS games and I ended up finding it surprisingly relaxing.

It's just the right amount of challenging, where it can feel like you won't be able to get out of a particular situation, but with enough work, you almost always can. 

I get a surprisingly high level of satisfaction from getting unstuck from a muddy bog and reloading a lost load of logs manually.

The graphics look great, even on older hardware, and the physics can be pretty entertaining (and frustrating).
The realistic feel of the trucks and how they interact with the enviroment.

Mudrunner is a game that needs quite a bit of patience and love for big truck hauling in extreme conditions. Its simple in theory: just drive around and take wood to where its supposed to go. But the environment is really unforgiving when it comes to getting there.

As you'd expect, you'd be driving trucks through the mud. And this game has a deep physics engine that a.) models the traction, power, and speed of your truck and b.) models the slippery terrain you'll be going through.

Personally, I think the slippery terrain physics are exaggerated, but only because the maps are only about 2 kilometers x 2 kilometers large (about 1.2 miles x 1.2 miles) so instead of making larger maps they make you move slower through the mud.

But since the traction is low, it may take you at least half an hour or more to drive a kilometer. Which isn't so bad gameplay-wise, since it emulates driving a long period of time through a much larger map.

Anyway, game itself has some wicked awesome looking graphics, real-time ground deformation, trees being pushed around, tires deforming, etc. So its quite entertaining to watch because there's almost no other game like this. Once you see your truck sluggishly trying to push through a waterlogged road, with all the ground and water graphics on you'll see how unique the game graphics and physics are. You'll also be using cranes (optional on casual difficulty) to load the logs onto trucks and that is a minigame onto itself with pretty accurate log physics so you need to carefully adjust your crane etc.

All in all, Mudrunner is a graphically impressive game that does admittedly look a little too gray so I suggest you install ReShade to up the saturation and improve contrast.

But it is like I said, graphically impressive. To drive through unforgiving terrain with trucks and environments modelled with amazing detail is visually pleasing, but also rewarding if you execute it properly. You need a lot of patience or you'll literally drop your load or flip your truck, so its not meant for people with really short attention spans.

What I suggest you do is have some music going, or a podcast, or personally I watch documentaries while driving. Of course, DON'T WATCH TV WHILE DRIVING IN REAL LIFE, but in a game you can do whatever.

What you get in return is a fun, challenging game of driving trucks through harsh terrain.

Great Off-Road simulator with near enough authentic mud physics. Challenging in some maps which is good because it gets you thinking about what trucks and attachments to use effectively.  Need to watch that fuel gauge with some of the trucks, be weary and plan your routes wisely!! Overall a good game to muck about in and pass the time. Especially fun if you just want a game to jump in and try different objectives.. recommend trying to get all watch-points with just the jeep is fun and at times a real brain stormer =P

I truly enjoyed this game. This series has potential and there's really nothing else out there like it. 

The fact that this is just an upgraded version of the original Spintires is a little ok by me as a lot of the time that's what games do, get better, and you can't exactly just make that into a DLC.

HOWEVER the fact that the developers have in my own words "sold out" to being an exclusive on epic games store with [b]Snowrunner[/b] and not even showing plans of it being on Steam. I can understand that they would get much better cuts on profits and whatnot but this does not help consumers one bit. I also realize that we don't really want Steam to have a monopoly on games, but with the other many launchers such as Bethesda, Blizzard, EA, Epic Games ETC... I am having to deal with the many accounts and services many of which are much less friendly to use than Steam. Some of the launchers I can understand having a good few of their own games released such as Blizzard's Battlenet but am still not too happy with so many of them existing right now.

All I want is to be able to buy my games on whatever platform works best for me and offers me the best features and support as a consumer.

Multiplayer is great with friends but the play-style doesn't lend itself so well to random players - you're lucky if they stay around long enough to complete the mission...
Improved since Spintires...would recommend and buy for friends.

This game is scary addictive. 

It's a bit confusing to figure out how the progression points work in multiplayer to unlock new vehicles (discovering vehicles on the map, unlocking garages, etc all build up "progression points" which then unlock vehicles when you finish each map - just because you "unlock" a vehicle on the map does not mean you will unlock it as a vehicle to choose from when selecting maps).

But the multiplayer is fun, the driving is addicting, and it's a lot of fun to explore and see where you can go with your vehicles! Easily feel I've got my money's worth with this one.

EDIT 2: Game is dead. No updates/patches since August 2019. Seems to have been abandoned for SnowRunner. Changed to not recommended.

EDIT: There was some drama between the developers of Spintires and MudRunner. They are both built on the same engine. I would suggest doing your own research on which would be the better purchase.

Spintires: Mudrunner is a great game! I came to it when I desperately needed a break from run-of-the-mill racing or car games and stayed because it is gorgeous and incredibly entertaining! It's not about racing, it's about navigating rough and unyielding terrain. It makes driving large vehicles slowly fun and exciting! For anyone who loves to pilot or drive in a game but wants more or something different than racing, this is THE game! You can enjoy the challenges or normal objectives of the official maps, or just download some custom maps and vehicles and enjoy some incredible rock-crawling or country crusining.

Spintires was the original game, and after the original publisher went AWOL on the devs, they decided to reboot the game with this title, MudRunner, Focus Home as the publisher.

Now suddenly development on the original has started again, together with a new DLC and nobody knows what's up. It's hard to put trust in a dev that seemed so transparent at first, and now does things like this. So no, I cannot recommend this game anymore.

I REALLY LIKED the game through the first stage (tutorials) and then on to the "challenges", the end of the first that made me cry. The tutorials are very comprehensive and even without a steering wheel etc., playing with a keyboard wasn't a problem at all.

The ONLY reason I would NOT recommend this game at the moment is because the first of the "challenges" asks you to reverse a truck with a trailer. While reversing shouldn't be a problem at all, reversing with a TRAILER really can make one sweat unless you're really experienced with these sort of games.

1) The catchment area of the trailer AFTER reversing is 'absolute'. No room for errors. I believe some relief should be granted to newbies at least.

2) If there was an option like ATS or ETS where AI parking is available and you get lesser XP or lesser points, this game would have been awesome.

I hope they add it in a future patch or something.

The above (so far) is the ONLY reason I would stop playing the game even after buying all its DLCs.

The Graphics are superb and so is the physx.

I love this game, and I never do this, but I'm changing my review to negative. This game in itself is more like an expansion to Spintires than its own release. I didn't mind so much because both were pretty affordable. But now that they're relasing Snowrunner on Epic store instead of here, and pricing it as a full game is the limit for me. 

I'm not changing my review to negative because I'm butthurt, or out of principle, but because I genuinely cannot recommend this game to someone getting into the series. I don't recommend paying full price for this game, only to have to pay full price for what is basically just another expansion on another platform. 

If this game goes on sale for under $10, then I would say it's worth it, but buyer beware that future expansions will be priced as full games.

This game is revolutionary in the way the game handles terrain physics, suspension/chassis physics, and just basically everything it says on the can. 
It has it's bugs and occasional instability, but 90% of the time that can be fixed (with exeption of a third party mod damaging the game) by simply restarting the game. 
This game is great fun for anyone who wants to do a serious logging sim, or for anyone who just wants to explore the world around them.

On the topic of Snowrunner, I feel that the developers are making a grave mistake in having the game being ran off the Epic Games launcher, as Epic is 40%(+-) owned by China. Epic also has a rather poorly secured way of placing money into one's account, where you either use paypal, or your personal bank account number, which I'd say nobody is comfortable using.
Snowrunner looks amazing, but I, among many, many others, shall not purchase it until it is put onto Steam.

Please consider putting Snowrunner on Steam and giving it Workshop integration, as you would make so much more money than having it on Epic.

MudRunner is where you need to be for now and for those of you curious here is my opinion on snowrunner.

Here are some things, not all of them, I've noticed and DO NOT LIKE:

1. You cannot short cut the game by prestaging trucks and trailers.
2. winching stops the driving of the truck you are trying to winch. Why can't i pull and have the truck reverse or drive fwd at the same time??
3. the auto center of the steering is REALLY annoying to me. i love the hard core mode on mudrunner because you feel the fight of the terrain. snowrunner is one difficulty and doesn't allow you to turn off auto center.
4. you can skip time with no cost to fuel (as far as i can tell)
5. this is probably the most insignificant dislike: i want that legacy camera. its default to a new "better" camera for people you can handle the way the OG players like it. thankfully there is an option for the legacy camera to be on. and it's better than the original on because it allows for more field of view.
6. cannot track multiple missions at once.. this is HUGE to me because, working in logistics for my career, we need to be able to multitask otherwise the military stuff i work on won't be able to support and defend the people of the country and constitution. It's weird that it's a offroad logistics game but you cannot, in single player, multitask. Obviously multiple players allow for multiple material movement. but i'm not sure they can track other missions to benefit the group. none of the people i know and play with own the game yet.
7. the road still feels like ice... the lighter the vehicle the more you slide.. why cant the road be grippy?? we waited for how long and we get no texture or feeling for the handling of the truck on the road...
8.quick winching.. its just easier sure but there is no telling what i'm going to attach too. it can be good in a muddy scramble but still.. Oh and the other benefit is if you spam the quick winch while trying to pull a stuck truck out you can use it like a snatch strap. which is the best use for quick winching i've found.
9. Minor things here. Regarding cab view: get the hands out of my face... lol or give me the option. and why is the horn so friggin delayed??? like you hit the button and 4 parsecs later your horn goes off?
10. mod.io support / epic store only.. seriously? epic is trash and none of my friends will buy the game because steam is actually WAY better. I know there are some bennies for devs not going with steam but honestly... you'll reach a bigger market and already have a workshop function for the community.. Mod.io looks great but it's just one more 3rd party thingy to sort of slow down people who like mods but don't know how to make them and don't want to spend the time to learn how to integrate an external website.

Now for ten things I DO LIKE:

1. Non-pavement surfaces have been significantly improved visually and feeling wise.
2. winching to weaker trees can break the tree and the winch point is gone. I love the realism feel of this.
3. truck customization out the bat. this is good because it will lessen the immediate want for mods even though i've already dug through the first few that are available.
4. the missions. there are a ton.
5. the landscapes are huge and driving takes a scaled amount of time that feel right.
6. discoverable upgrades and equipment
7. the length of the day and night cycle
8. i like that if you have a road truck you can build it into a more off-road type truck.
9 the variety of cargo and missions is pretty good.
10. you can buy vehicles and build your fleet.

This isn't all of the things I like or dislike but this is some of my list... One extra thing i didn't like for the realism guys and modders that do a killer job with lifted truck mods.. The "lift upgrade" just hurts my soul... those control arms are literally vertical on the 1500 chevy... ugh... i can't wait til we let the modders get there hands on this game. You modding pros and amatures made the game waaaay better. I'm thankful for the platform the devs created... but dang.. they've never been in a trail rig or lifted truck in their lift from the looks of it..

Thanks for your time.. feel free to add to these likes and dislikes. it's all a matter of opinion.. don't bash mine.

This review is for Snowrunners, since Saber decided not to allow reviews by using EPICFail Games. I'm so glad I refused to buy this game until I seen it tested. I'm tired of game devs charging a premium price for broken games! Whats worse is, literally every bug I've seen SHOULD have been fixed during a beta test as they are literally Alpha level bugs. Come on, no collision on assets such as landscape rocks, bridges, and even INSIDE the garage!?!?! You're joking right? Nope. Coming out of the garage and your truck can't move because the whole body turns due to some weird snap mapping glitch that makes your truck think turning the wheels should command the body to move instead of the tires..... This is basic game crap, and it literally breaks the game when it happens. I watched a streamer roll completely down a mountain because he was going to use a cliff rock to drive on and it turns out, there was no collision, so the 20 minutes it took him to climb up there was squashed as he rolls down the mountain face to the bottom. What an outrage. I'm going to thumbs down mudrunners because of it. Why? because you can't tell me you didn't know about these bugs before launch. Bet you were popping champagne and partying it up on launch day though, weren't you? Pathetic.

It's really difficult to say something positive now after the recent developments. The game is fine, there is a big modding community and it's fun to play for a bit every once in a while. But what's happening in the background is a mystery. Originally Spintires was the original game, and after the original publisher went AWOL on the devs, they decided to reboot the game with this title, MudRunner, Focus Home as the publisher.

Now suddenly development on the original has started again, together with a new DLC and nobody knows what's up. It's hard to put trust in a dev that seemed so transparent at first, and now does things like this. So no, I cannot recommend this game anymore.

After the desaster with the original Spintires the comunity bought into the idea of Mudrunner but only because improvements were said to come. However Mudrunner is basically Spintires with 2 more DLCs and after all that time after release not much changed. Now Snowrunner was announced with all the features and improvements that were already promised for Mudrunner. And as a cherry on top it only will be released in a gamestore that should not be named. 

The game is good. As was Spintires. But as a player who bought both games to support the devs I highly dislike this behaviour of promising, but not deliviering and finally publishing on another gamestore. I believe the devs can't be trusted with what they say and promise. So I can't recommend buying any of their games.

Same review as posted for Spintires: The Original Game:

"Perfect game for everyone who likes old russian horses such as KrAZ, URAL and MAZ. Not recommended for Greenpeace members - tons of burnt fuel just for the forest exploitation. Anyway, finding your way through the forest and tugging logs can be pretty relaxing. Great graphics, ingame physics and truck handling. Pleasant performance, no fatal bugs or crashes.
After some time you will find out that some objectives are kinda easy, I would probably appreciate more challenging difficulty."

+ There was a nice update of American trucks and maps but since that time the game seems to be idle. I guess the devs of original Spintires took the concept back and started to work on it again, so I would probably recommend to see the original game. To conclude the review, it was a nice attempt to save the concept of the original game.

Rating: 6/10

Graphics: 8/10 ; Not gonna lie, may look abit dated but the world and physics are quite amazing. If youre playing this just for the graphics then it will get boring fast.
Story: 5/10 ; No story at all. It is basically what you (or/and friends) make up as you play the bottomless list of maps to download and play from workshop.
Gameplay: 5/10 ; Quite satisfying controls. It is not too sim or too arcady, quite in the middle and the gameplay itself is satisfying. But the gameplay loop is not for everyone. Again will be better if play with friends as the challenges will be more fun with help.

Let's start with cons:
- The game is relatively short and repetitive. A few different loads, and other kinds of vehicles, could have been nice.

Now the pros:
- Graphically good, intuitive UI, pleasant to play.
- Extremely well optimised, can run 720p on a potato, 1080p with high settings on any 2018+ GPU and iGPU - for the latter you might want 8 GB RAM to avoid lag though.
- Good sound engine.
- Excellent difficulty level : casual is easy and stiil slightly challenging. hardcore is really challenging yet perfectly feasible. Eventually a super-hardcore mode would have been nice, but it's easy to create your own super-hardcore by setting your own limitations.

REDONE REVIEW 3/9/20

This is a great game that offers tons of diverse gameplay.

The base game is centered around Russia. You start off and are tasked with delivering logs across the map to a Lumber Mill.

There are plenty of trucks to use. Plenty of 6x6 trucks, plenty of 4x4's and a few 8x8's.

Pros:

Wide range of vehicles, from a UAZ Jeep to a MAZ 7410 missile hauler.

Great maps, they are designed very interesting and are very fun to offroad in.

Mod support. There are maps, trucks, trailers, anything you want mods support it.

Cons:

Abandoned. They have moved to "Snowrunner" on the Epic Games store which means no mod support, customer support there is awful, and you dont have all your steam achievments etc.

Modding is pretty dead on the workshop. Theres a few who keep going but its basically dead. If you want new mods go to mudrunnermods or something online.

Not enough official content. Honestly.


Other then that, a great game. I rate it a 7/10 and would recommend getting it on sale. Just dont get Snowrunner as you will get yourself screwed over HEAVILY. You can also go to Spintires the Original Game if you want a game not abandoned.

Good game, can get tedious, however, its great fun and not many games out there that replicate this play style.

If you're into offroading you'll love it!

Its a Good off road game for people who wish they had a 4x4

Listen, do you like a bit of problem solving? Moving logs across vast swathes of terrain not meant for your average goods vehicle? Do you like battering differentials? Well this is the game for you!
Lovely, atmospheric visuals that really give the feel that you're somewhere bleak - beautiful V8 and V12 diesel engine grunts and turbo whines - you've run out of diesel?! Go get some!
Tricky maps that require scouting for watchpoints in smaller 4x4's, then working out your routes and finding hidden, heavy duty Ukranian/Russian vehicles to get your timber moving to the sawmills have got me hooked.
Took me a bit of time to get used to using my Steam controller, but now I've mastered that I find myself taking on harder challenges - not starting with big vehicles, but making do with what I find in the wilderness.
Then there's the amount of mods out there, a lot of which that are done very, very well!
I just wish the hud in cockpit mode was done better, but some mods have done just that. Overall, I flippin' love Mudrunner!

A lot of fun getting into it and doing the missions with the default vehicles but the mods are what really drive us to play. My buddies and I get on these massive, incredible community-made maps in real-world community made trucks and just go wheeling together. Lazy days involve less extreme crawling and we just ride trails, check out the waterfalls and do random stuff like see if we can drive our Dodge Rams, Ford Rangers and Chevy Trailblazers across rivers. Mod vehicles are a lot more generous when it comes to equipping extra repair kits, fuel, etc so it's easy to play by yourself, winch, repair and refuel your truck all by yourself. If you find yourself on your roof, just swap to another one of your trucks on the map and BOOM - you're now on a mission to rescue yourself lol...

Okay, so after some time, I feel like I need to reevaluaute the review..

Let's take this game as it is now - a separate title (for whatever reason). It offers hours of ... well, fun, if you enjoy driving through muddy roads and cooperating while trying to come through the obsticles every map is full with.

While it perhaps isn't a game one would play alone, it is really enjoyable to challenge yourself with one of the challenges the devs prepared. What might draw more people's attention is the multiplayer mode, which offers loads of fun while remaining a chill-out game. Even though it may get boring from time to time, I always end up playing it when I just don't want any action coming, lay back and relax with the music and a few friends in the background.

With the base game, you get some free DLCs containing new maps and vehicles, which were (and probably still will be) released throughout the years. The physics are stunning and although the difficulty is maybe sometimes exaggerated, there's nothing more satisfying than completing any of the maps. The price maybe isn't that friendly to everyone, but every now and then, there's a sale and it's definitely worth getting at lower cost.

If you get it cheap it is a unique experience I have never had in other games.
It is a slow paced burn so don't expect anything too exiting.
